title: donald clark a tribute
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsDonald Clark was for  years the convivial, larger-than-le host at The George Hotel in Inveraray, a notable bon viveur and one of the most colourful characters in Argyll. He died aged  on January  after a short illness.Latterly, his mobility hampered by a leg injury, he would sit in the corner of The George public bar on an over-sized carved wooden stool. From his throne he dispensed news, advice and anecdotes – albeit not always historically accurate. His inimitable irony, perfectly-timed humour and the occasional reprimand to a wayward customer were all fuelled by a generous glass.As former president of the Scottish Licensed Trade Association and Keeper of the Quaich, Donald knew the intricacies of the business intimately from personal experience. His taste was eclectic and his appetite substantial, extending from Dom Perignon and Saint-Émilion Grand Cru to Tennent’s lager and Glen Dronach single malt. On a hot day he’d have an icy Martini or a gin and tonic, proportionately scaled up in a pint glass. Being askedhe had time for a quick ‘small one’, he would reply: #I’ll decide the size for myself,you don’t mind.#The records suggest that his frequent claim to be Scottish Slimmer of the Year, after getting his weight down from  stone to  stone, was fancul.Big D, as he was often called, was fastidious about standards in the little public bar, training his regulars to clear tables of empty glasses and plates promptly, and to keep the log fire stoked on winter evenings.If one of his regulars turned up untypically well-dressed, Donald would raise an eyebrow in mild surprise:  #What’s the occasion for the suit   A funeral   Your latest marriage   Or has your court case come up #In summer, an erratic stream of foreign tourists would have their first encounter with a Scottish pub, standing in the doorway bewildered as to what happens next – sit or stand  Fight their way to the mobbed bar or go to a table and wait for the non-existent waitress  Donald would call them over to his corner and was soon plying them with drinks, food and conversation, not infrequently paying the entire bill for his astonished guests.When a tourist asked him about the quaint red GPO telephone box in Church Square, he told them: #We have the fastest modern communications here – telephone, teletext and tell Donald.#Donald was a Francophile and loved his summers in Collioure, where #Le Grand Ecossais# was almost as well-known as in Argyll. A fixture of the local bars and restaurants, and frequently crossing the border to patronise Spanish hostelries, he revelled in the region’s seafood, wine and culture.His hobbies included cooking, opera, reading and lively conversation on a sweeping range of topics from local history to civil engineering. His knowledge was genuinely wide, but when occasionally encountering someone with a superior command of the topic in question, he would quickly change the subject and admonish: “Och, you’re showing off now.”Donald Clark was born on  July , in Rotten Row hospital, Glasgow. He was the youngest child of Donald Clark and Elizabeth Inglis, following by nine years his only sibling, Fiona.His early years were spent in Inveraray where family le revolved around his parents’ hotel in the little white-washed town.He was schooled at Inveraray Primary and Larchfield in Helensburgh, then Strathallan from  to  where he acquired his love of sports. Contrary to what his dimensions in later le would suggest, he was athletic when young, excelling at rugby and playing for his school and West of Scotland First XV and the old boys’ As.Donald also enjoyed curling, motor boating, snow skiing and water-skiing, where his party piece was to mono-ski down Loch Fyne while drinking a pint of beer.Although not a shinty player, he used his sports experience to coach the Inveraray team in the s and like his father chaired the club. In , he flamboyantly arrived in Inverness by helicopter for Inveraray#s Camanachd Final against Kingussie.

title: mysterious island monk explored in new book
story: Ellis ButcherUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe prehistoric and medieval landmarks of western Scotland take centre stage in a new book telling the story of one of the greatest northern saints.The Man Who Gave his Horse to a Beggar, by John Connell, follows in the footsteps of Aidan of Lindisfarne, taking the reader on an odyssey through Ireland and northern Britain.The Scotland section features Iona, where the charismatic holy man lived as a monk before embarking on a dangerous journey to preach to the pagan English.The lavishly-illustrated book features photographs from award-winning writer and exhibition designer Phil Cope, and is a biography of a man about whom little is known until now.It takes the reader to the rocky outcrop of Dunadd, seat of the warrior kings of Dál Riata, and explores the ancient monuments of Kilmartin Glen, near  Lochgilphead.Temple Wood Stone Circle and the standing stones of Nether Largie were visible in Aidan’s time too, while Dunadd would have been a thriving cosmopolitan centre.It was in this part of what is now Argyll and Bute that Aidan is thought to have encountered his future lord, St Oswald of Northumbria, an exiled Anglo-Saxon prince living in the court of the Gaelic kings.When he ed to reclaim his rightful kingdom at the point of a sword – a story that inspired JRR Tolkien’s The Lord of the Rings – Oswald invited Aidan to establish a monastery on Lindisfarne basing it on the Iona model.Part-biography and part-pilgrimage, The Man Who Gave his Horse To A Beggar takes the reader back in time but also asks what lessons this neglected holy man might have for our own troubled times.Named in honour of one of Aidan’s most revealing acts, the work explores why Aidan has so often been overlooked and aims to restore him to his rightful place as one of the greatest figures in Irish and British history.Mr Connell, age , a former journalist, said: #Iona was among the most memorable destinations in our epic travels through Britain and Ireland.#We arrived in late March of , before the Easter rush. The beauty and calm of the island made a lasting impression on me.#The monuments of Kilmartin Glen are also at the very heart of the book’s major themes, including kingship and the sacredness of landscape.#And it was at Dunadd that Aidan would have seen the kings of Dál RiataPortals to this other-world still survive, suggested by mountains, forgotten ruins, holy wells and standing stones, crosses and caves, said Mr Connell.Born in Newcastle, he now lives in Cumbria, England, with his partner and their daughter.He previously worked for titles including The Edinburgh Evening News, with bylines in The Scotsman and Scotland on Sunday.The book has been published by Culture and Democracy Press and is available to purchase online through Amazon for £.

title: nature makes swift return to argyll
story: Susan WindramUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsBefore coronavirus restrictions were introduced, Argyll Bird Club provided monthly field trip outings around mainland Argyll led by experienced bird watchers.With most bird surveying suspended as a result of the coronavirus pandemic, the club is relieved that it has now chosen a species which can be surveyed from home and within the government advice.Swts are slightly larger than swallows and have an all dark plumage with only a short forked tail. They feed on flying insects and spend most of their le in the air , usually coming down to earth to breed. They are fast fliers often chasing one another over buildings when they give a screeching call.Swts arrive back in Argyll in early May and breed in some of the towns, villages and other buildings in Argyll. They spend around three months in Argyll, departing in early-mid August, to their wintering grounds in Africa.The British Trust for Ornithology’s Breeding Bird Survey indicates that the population of Swts in Scotland has declined by around  per cent since . A similar decline has taken place in England and Wales. The reasons for this decline are not fully known but are believed to be related to changes in insect numbers and a lack of nesting sites as buildings are modernised.Argyll is at the north-western limit of the world range of Swts. Their distribution and numbers in Argyll is not well known and the purpose of the Argyll Bird Club Survey is to try to find out the size of the breeding population and where they remain.If you have a swt nesting in your building, or near you, or would like to take part in this survey further information is available at http:argyllbirdclub.org argyll-surveysFor more information about Argyll Bird Club, contact the Argyll bird recorder Jim Dickson by email at Argyllbirder@outlook.

title: ex-radio-borders-dj-went-rome-become-priest
story: A Galashiels priest-in-training has spoken to the Borderabout his time in the Vatican and what it was like being filmed by the BBC for a new documentary, which is being aired this weekend.Former Radio Borders DJ Bobby Taylor was in his fth year at The Scots College in Rome when filming for the BBCs Priest School began in September . He is now coming to the end of his sixth year.The -year-old, whose mother is Catholic, had always had the inclination to become a priest, even applying to train before, but for reasons-unknown never followed up on these applications.It wasnt untilgoing to confession in Melbourne in , not long after the passing of his father two years earlier, that he started seeing a path to priesthood laid out clearly in front of him ndash particularly thanks to guidance from his own parish-priest in Galashiels.When we spoke to Bobby, who is back in Galashiels, he told us: "Since filming ended, the most visible thing thats changed is that when were in Rome now were wearing collars. Candidacy is the final step before being admitted as a member of the clergy. So I suppose our wardrobe is the most visible change."When you get into sixth year especially, you start realising youre closer to the end of your time in Rome than you ever have been."Although seven years, when youre in your first year, feels like a very, very long time, when you realise youre a year or maybe  months away from finishing up, you realise just how quickly its all gone ndash how little time youve got left in a beautul city like Rome."Youre looking even more forward than you ever were to getting back and doing what it is that you went to Rome in the first place to do, which is to become a priest."The programme follows a group of young Scots over a year of their seven-year degree, showing the inner workings of the seminary, its history, and how the young seminarians navigate their journey to priesthood.The colleges training isnt for every student, however. The school has an approximate  percent drop-out rate as the young men learn more of what God is calling them to do, and as they face the sometimes hard-to-accept vows which they must take."Every guy is dferent," said Bobby. "To be honest, Im not  percent sure  percent is the rate of drop out Ive experienced over the past few years Ive been there. Theres only been two or three guys out of - whove left."Me, personally, my first year was probably my toughest year. It was a big adjustment from that freedom I had, and having gone from earning quite a healthy wage working at sea, then going to seminary in a foreign country ndash it was quite a challenge."There was a period where I did have to really, seriously, pray about it and think about what I was being called to do."I think everybody goes through it, and I think its a good thing that everybody goes through because ultimately thats what seminary is about.,params: .push"Seven years isnt a number plucked out of mid-air, its a period where youre doing a lot of study but youre also doing a lot of work to understand what it is youre being called to do, andits being called to priesthood because its not a light undertaking, its quite a serious undertaking ndash but a good one, and a positive one."And the problems facing Bobby and his fellow seminarians have only grown since the COVID- lockdown.He added: "From about six weeks ago being in Rome and studying in the university with my class of about  other guys, Im now sitting in a dining room in a Catholic church house in Galashiels studying on my own."So things have changed quite a bit. But study still continues, its not like theyve stopped. Theres been a couple of weeks, this week and last week, which would have been the Easter holidays anyway."Although we may be spread out, back to our home countries, were still persevering with study."And in June, Bobby hopes to sit his exams which will see him move into his seventh year at the Scots College. However, he intends to continue with a further year of study once his seven years are over to focus on his specialist course.Priest School will be broadcast on BBC Scotland on Sunday, April , at .pm and will later be available on BBC iPlayer.

title: borders-golf-club-asks-donations-ensure-survival
story: A BORDERS golf club fighting to survive the coronavirus pandemic has raised thousands of pounds in the coursersquos th anniversary year.Torwoodlee Golf Club, near Galashiels, has launched an online fundraising page in a bid to stay afloat.Club chairman Robin Brydon told the Borderthat generous donors gave a total of pound, within seven days.Mr Brydon said: ldquoItrsquos been amazing and wersquore all totally humbled by the donations so far.The JustGiving pagedescribes the parkland course as one of the ldquofinest in Scotland, but goes on to outline the challenges faced by the club, which closed last month.A statement reads: ldquoDue to the devastating COVID- pandemic crisis affecting us all, the club now faces an uncertain future and we therefore need as much money as possible to survive the pandemic and beyond.Speaking to this newspaper, Mr Brydon revealed that the original aim was to generate pound,, but a wave of donations has prompted the target to be raised to pound,.Mr Brydon said: ldquoFor people who are not going to the golf club at the moment and spending money on teas and coffees and entry fees and who are maybe financially better off as theyrsquore not spending money, wersquod be gratefulthey could donate a little bit every week to the club.Asked what the money will be spent on, Mr Brydon said: ldquoIt all goes into the pot and itrsquos just to ensure survival. Wersquove obviously got a lot of outgoings with machinery rentals and buggy rentals and bills to play.Clubhouse staff have been put on furlough, according to Mr Brydon, but a greenkeeper continues to maintain the course, established in .Mr Brydon said the club has around  members, but ex-members have also been keen to show their concern.ldquoWersquove seen donations from as far away as Australia, said Mr Brydon. ldquoWersquove also had money from Aberdeen and from former members in Chepstow.A third of the clubrsquos income has traditionally come from visitors, said Mr Brydon, who explained the coursersquos appeal.ldquoItrsquos a really lovely course ndash the views and the scenery and the layout. A lot of the visitors have been coming for  years, he said.Mr Brydon put the chances of survival at around  per cent, adding: ldquoEverybody has got to remain positive, but there are so many unknowns at the moment.Outlining how much the club means to him, he said: ldquoIrsquove been a member for  years, so itrsquos a huge part of my le and my familyrsquos le. Itrsquos a spectacular place to be ndash we all take it for granted.Peebles Golf Club is one of the other clubs running a similar fundraising drive.

title: royal-mail-launches-thumbs-postie-campaign---get-involved
story: Royal Mail is asking its customers to show their appreciation for their postie by giving them a lsquothumbs uprsquo - from a safe two metres distance - as they go about their rounds.Heres what you need to know.Contact free deliveryA spokesman for the Royal Mail said: "The initiative is a simple way for the public to say thanks and stay connected with their local postmen and women, while respecting the Governmentrsquos social distancing rules."Giving a thumbs up is also a handy reminder not to reach out to try and take parcels direct from postmen and women to ensure contact free delivery."Royal Mailrsquos postmen and postwomen are at the heart of the communities in which they work. title: factory-gets-visited-army-ppe-can-sent-across-uk
story: A BORDERS factory boss says army trucks visited this month to collect personal protective equipmentfor hospital staff in England.Alistair Cameron, managing director of Scotmas Group, is employees, according to Mr Cameron.Hospitals will not use the gel, said Mr Cameron, because ldquothey require an alcohol sanitiser.The NHS has been purchasing other products, however, including PPE and water treatment kit, Mr Cameron revealed.ldquoWersquore already working with  NHS trusts throughout the UK, providing water disinfectant treatments, said Mr Cameron.He said treatment plants are being set up in some of the temporary hospitals which have been built to handle virus patients.ldquoIn most cases, the sites chosen for these hospitals are simply not designed to cope with the rigours of a healthcare environment, so it is vital that the water is treated effectively, Mr Cameron said.Some of the products collected by the armywere being delivered to the emergency Nightingale hospital in London, Mr Cameron said.Staff in Kelso have performed admirably in recent weeks, according to Mr Cameron, despite the increase in workload.ldquoOur staff have been absolutely fantastic ndash theyrsquove never shirked from doing whatrsquos needed, he said.Meanwhile, in Selkirk, the local branch of the Guthrie Group has been supplying PPE to the Borders General Hospitaland key workers, according to manager Alan Skeldon.ldquoLocal companies have been great so far trying to buy from us and hopefully that will continue after this period of uncertainty, said Mr Skeldon.Reflecting on the delivery to the BGH, he said: ldquoObviously those guys are key at the moment and itrsquos good to make sure theyrsquore safe - and the feedback has been good as well.

title: royal-family-share-chocolate-cupcake-recipe-celebrate-queen-elizabeths-94th-birthday
story: The Royal Pastry Chefs have shared arecipe to make chocolate cupcakes and celebrate The Queens th birthday.In a statement made via Facebook, The Royal Family said: "Happy birthday to Her Majesty!"To celebrate The Queens birthday we are sharing a chocolate cupcake recipe from The Royal Pastry Chefs."If you or a loved one are celebrating a special occasion during isolation why not treat yourself to some#royalbakes  Remember to share your creations with us!"Heres how to make them.Ingredients cake sponges - g vinegarml milkml vegetable oilg butter eggsml of vanilla essenceg of self-raising flourof cocoa powderg caster sugarg bicarbonate of sodag white chocolate chipscupcake casesIngredients Buttercream Toppingg of high percentage dark chocolateg butterg icing sugarOption to also use Royal icing, instead of buttercream:Royal icing available pre-made in shops.Add food colouring to create dferent coloursCake sponge method:Preheat the oven to  CCombine the flour, sugar, cocoa powder and bicarbonate of soda into a mixing bowlWhisk the eggs in a separate jug, with the vanilla essence, melted butter, oil, milk and vinegarSlowly add the wet mixture into the dry mixture, little by littleEnsure the batter is smooth with no lumpsFinally add the chocolate chips Lay the cupcake cases onto a trayUse a metal spoon to equally ide the mixture into the casesBake for around - minutes, take out of the oven when golden and springy on touchLeave to coolButtercream icing methodCream the sugar and butter together, until light and creamyAdd in the warm melted chocolateIf you have a piping bag to hand, pipe the icing on the top of cakes for decoration Royal icing methodIf decorating with royal icing, roll the icing out and cut into circular disksLay the disc over the cupcake and mould to required shapeEat and enjoy!

title: bgh-site-gets-new-drive-through-centre-virus-testing
story: A NEW drive-through test centre has been set up at the Borders General Hospitalto identy health staff with coronavirus.The facility, located at the main car park, will offer tests to workers with appointments.It replaces a previous test centre where on the BGH site.Tests will mainly be given to health and social care staff, according to NHS Borders.A health board statement reads: "A temporary drive-through COVID- testing centre has been set up on the BGH site, positioned in the main carpark."A testing facility had previously been available at another location on the BGH site, however this new arrangement ensures further staff and patient safety and convenience."The drive through testing centre will predominantly be used for Health and Social Care staff testing at this time."It is important to note that attending this facility is by appointment only and people should not turn up without having been invited to do so."If anyone has symptoms of coronavirus, they are advised to stay at home for seven days.The most common symptoms are a new persistent cough and a fever high temperature .According to NHS Borders, your symptoms worsen during home isolation or are no better after sevendays then you should phone NHS  on .You should no longer call your GP practice regarding coronavirus symptoms.Full guidance and information is available on NHS Informrsquos coronavirus page.

title: borders-artist-runs-online-classes-lockdown
story: A BORDERS artist has spent lockdown running online art classes from the comfort of her home.Maria Koeva, an architect, began the Easy Sketching Club Art Challenge on April  to encourage people to pick up a brush, pencil, or pastel.The Melrose resident said: "Everyones grateful for the opportunity to keep occupied and boost their skills."Every day, Maria issues a prompt to let participants know what the classs theme will be, giving them a chance to prepare.She said: "As I cant do the workshops in person, for my sake, and attendants, I decided to run them online."Art and painting have always been a good way to spend your time."And when people dont know where to start, having the prompts helps them to plan ahead."I have my own preference but Im trying to show dferent styles, using pencils, pastels, water colours, so everyone can join in."Maria, originally from Moscow, Russia, started the Easy Sketching Club in October last year. She offered in-person classes through Natural Crafts, Melrose, and afterschool clubs at Melrose Primary School.For each day of the challenge, Maria sets a dferent topic. So far, the artists have covered themes including the Eildons, interiors, Russian dolls, parrots and ndash immediately prior to Marias interview with this newspaper ndash fast food."My favourite has to be the kingfisher shyndash it turned out so well," said Maria. "The burger I did today was fun to do, too."Those taking part in the daily art project cover a ied age range. One family span three generations - a daughter, mother and grandmother - all participating whileobserving social-distancing guidelines.Marias page has  followers, and the numbers watching her livestreams y each day, but Maria told us: "There are roughly  people who participate. And the people who do it, feedback has been good."Although the lockdown has meant Maria is unable to run her workshops as normal, she has found some benefits to being at home."Ive always painted," she said, "and Im an architect by trade so Ive always painted in some way or another."But now I have the opportunity to paint more regularly."I really enjoy doing the workshops but Id run them in a dferent format in the future. As long as there is a demand for them, Ill keep going."The Easy Sketching Club Art Challenge is set to finish at the end of the month, with one lucky artist winning a pound voucher to use at Simply Delicious, Melrose, once lockdown restrictions have been lted.The winner of the voucher will be chosen at random from all the pieces of art Maria will have received over the course of the challenge, and participants will have some extra time to catch up on any challenges they missed.For more information, and to join the challenge, visit: www.facebook easysketchingclub

title: peebles-ruined-litter-says-eco-hero
story: A DISAPPOINTED environmentalist has criticised litter-droppers in Peeblesshire following his most recent clean-up effort.Jeremy Stuart-Menteth, , frequently undertakes tidy-ups in the Peebles area.But now the retired osteopath has become fed up with some residents selfish habits.He said: "Theres an exorbitant amount of litter ndash I think people are becoming litter blind."Since moving to the region in , Mr Stuart-Menteth has tried to pick up any rubbish he has come across.However, the Stobo resident has become increasingly frustrated by the mess, believing it puts Peeblesshire "in a bad light".He said: "Peebles in particular is becoming bad for it, and I think its a reflection on society as a whole."Weve seen reports on vandalism in the town, and litters one step from that. Theres no respect."Most of the rubbish probably dates to pre-lockdown, Mr Stuart-Menteth suspects.He has noticed fewer motorists around ndash who he believes are the main culprits of the littering ndash since local attractions have closed their doors.Mr Stuart-Menteth told us: "As with many others, Im fed up to the point of doing something."If I was looking for houses now, I would be put off."On a grander scale its not always noticeable, but it does get depressing to see."Its wrong how people mistreat the planet, especially when people see rubbish and dont pick it up ndash two wrongs dont make a right."A spokesman for Scottish Borders Council said: "We would ask all members of the public to play their part and place litter in a street bin or take it home to help keep our towns, villages and road side verges clean."Our Parks and Environment team continues to provide a street cleansing service, albeit resources are impacted at present by the coronavirus response."To report areas where litter is a problem, members of the public can use our website, or phone   ."

title: ice-cream-couple-using-van-help-vulnerable-folk
story: AN ICE cream van has stocked up with groceries and prescriptions to help Peeblesshire residents.Martha Gibson has run JM Ices for a decade, much to the delight of hundreds of kids.But now the popular Innerleithen resident has decided to requisition her vehicle in the fight against COVID-.She said: "Everyone knowsthey need anything they can come to Martha. Wersquove taken half the stock out of the van and filled it with bread, milk, pasta, rice, flour.Vulnerable folk and elderly people who cannot visit shops are able to draw on crucial assistance from Martha and her husband Brian.Martha said: ldquoThese folk canrsquot get out to do their shopping, so we do it for them. I now have two people on the van, one serving and the other dealing with cash. Wersquore following all the social distancing guidelines and using anti-bacterial products.ldquoMost elderly people only deal with cash, whereas others will just pay what they owe into my bank later."I ken mostly everyone and I know theyrsquoll pay me one way or another. As long as everyone gets what they need, thatrsquos whatrsquos important to me.Martha and Brian have been called ldquolesavers by grateful residents. Meanwhile, many families say the vans familiar tune has brought a bit of normality into the lives of confused children.And Marthas van boasts a bountul supply of goodies to "keep the bairns entertained".Martha said: ldquoWersquove stocked things like puzzles, bubbles, wee things for the bairns, just pocket money stuff for pound. Itrsquos not about making money for us, itrsquos about helping families.Serving their community is something that comes naturally to Martha and Brian, who say they always try to help those in need.Asked why she does so much, Martha said: ldquoI know what itrsquos like to struggle. Irsquove lived it, Irsquove been there. But I lived through a time when neighbours were neighbours."Yoursquod never go hungry - one family would give you a bag of tatties, the other some mince, between us wersquod put a meal together. You never did without.ldquoIrsquoll never forget that, and thatrsquos why I always help those in need. I do it because I want to gie a wee bit back to the community I love.And this is summed up perfectly by a member of the community who joined in the praise of this marvellous lady by writing: ldquoIf there were a lot more people like Martha, the world would be a better place.

title: netball-players-deliver-medicine-borders-town
story: NETBALL players in Peebles have been delivering medicine to people who cannot leave home.When sports fixtures were cancelled, members of the Stuart Netball Club contacted the Peebles Covid- Support Group.The athletes are now collecting prescriptions from Boots chemist and dropping them off in Peebles and nearby areas.Jodie Troup and Claire Mahon are among the players who jumped at the chance to lend a hand.They said: ldquoWe are thankful we can do something to support our community, especially when they have been so good at supporting us when we started our own club.ldquoWe deliver six days a week and we are helped by members of our households ."A few of the other girls help out on a Saturday to give us some time off.The women give up their time freely and pay for their own fuel.They said: ldquoMost people have been so lovely and very grateful. They really appreciate what wersquove done for them, which is so heart-warming."Some do need to remember we are only volunteers taking time out of our days and we donrsquot work for Boots. We do it because we want to help our community.

title: newstead-shows-incredible-kindness-lockdown
story: While the Borders adapts to the challenges posed by lockdown, community spirit is in full flow across the region. Newstead is no exception, with residents pulling together to help anyone in need.ldquoA small group of us recently came together, says Lisa Cowan, who coordinates the village resilience effort. ldquoWith such a high number of older people living in the village, we anticipated many may need extra support.A Facebook group called lsquoNewstead Village Chatrsquo group was soon launched, allowing the chance to share ideas and offer help. The group now boasts more than  members, according to Lisa.She says: ldquoThe Facebook group is a big success, but we quickly realised more needed to be done."As supermarket shelves were stripped, older people continued to head out looking for supplies. We felt there must be another way to help high risk groups."Equally, local businesses were worried about the virus affecting their trade. In order to help sustain all aspects of our community, wersquove tried to take a broad approach.One solution was the creation of the first Newstead Village Newsletter ndash a simple, four-page leaflet which included useful information and several helpline numbers. ldquoMelrose shops offering home deliveries were also included in the newsletter, says Lisa. ldquoWe put the information online but that excluded those without internet access. So, a printed version delivered to every home was essential.Local Volvo dealer John Cleland kindly offered to take care of the printing, while Gala Le said they would deliver. But these exciting plans looked to be scuppered with the imposition of lockdown.Thankfully, though, postman Keith Borthwick came to the rescue, explained Lisa.She says: "He made sure that every house received a copy of the newsletter with their mail. Feedback has been brilliant. Itrsquos proving a great resource to help people access local shops.The village has also created a highly productive WhatsApp group, which is proving to be a "great way" to keep in touch with residents in isolation, says local volunteer Sonia Kelly.ldquoShoppers message when theyrsquore heading out, and those in need then get in contact," says Sonia. "The system works well and is based on being neighbourly. Therersquos so much community activity taking place, itrsquos bringing everyone together in the most resourceful way.Jane McNeil is also one of Newsteadrsquos busy shoppers. ldquoI started volunteering because I wanted to help those who had made me feel welcome since moving to the village," she says."It started with a couple of neighbours and has grown since then. Irsquom a great believer in treating others as I would hope to be treated. With so many new friendships being forged, my hope is that after the pandemic, we can maintain this level of care for our neighbours.Another shopper is Jackie Kerr, who helps out a couple of the villages older residents. ldquoI shop a few times a week for Nancy Howieson, who is , and her mother Georgina Paterson ndash who recently celebrated her th birthday. They live separately and are usually very independent. So, itrsquos a dficult time for them now, but Irsquom happy to help in any way I can.Nancy and Georgina are well known around Melrose, where they founded Tweedbank Art Club and put on regular shows. ldquoWe love to paint, says Nancy. ldquoWe are the best of friends and usually see each other every day. Mum has led an exciting le including travelling the world and being a maid at Buckingham Palace for Princess Alice. Shersquos a bit fed up as she likes to get out but is still managing to paint.Whilst her mother continues to paint her way through the lockdown, Nancy has been busy tackling her garden. ldquoI try not to bother folk, but my next-door neighbour has been such a help offering to cut my grass and digging out some tree roots. Everyone in the village is being really friendly.With so many currently living in isolation, volunteers are also reaching out by phone. ldquoIf people arenrsquot on the Internet, itrsquos easy for them to be left out, says Liz Ellis, who has lived in Newstead for  years. ldquoTherefore a few of us are making regular phone calls to people all over the village just to say hello, seethey need anything and have a friendly chat. Irsquove never experienced anything like this in Newstead before. I canrsquot get over the amount of support being offered everyone is desperate to help each other.,params: .pushThe Neate family are also playing their role in raising village spirits. Toby, aged nine, and his seven-year-old brother Rueben, along with other Newstead children, have been displaying colourful paintings in their windows and have decorated the village phone box with rainbows. ldquoIt makes us really happy that our art is helping to keep the village smiling, says Toby.Meanwhile, dad Tristan, who manages Neate Maintenance, has offered to help Newsteadrsquos army of NHS workers. ldquoThe pandemic is putting pressure on many key workers who are working extremely long hours. Im sure they have little time for gardening right now. In , Irsquod like to thank them by volunteering to their cut grass or do some weeding.Lisa, the resilience co-ordinator, says shes "never felt prouder" of the village.ldquoCoordinating the resilience group is a pleasure," she says. "Wersquore seeing so many incredible acts of kindness, often between complete strangers. Itrsquos heart-warming to be part of such a generous community.

title: borders-businesses-get-16-5m-coronavirus-support-funding
story: BORDERS businesses will have soon collectively received more than pound. million from the council as they struggle through the coronavirus pandemic.Scottish Borders Councilis managing a portion of the Scottish Governmentrsquos Business Support Fund.A total of , businesses have been approved for help so far, with payments taking the form of one-off grants worth pound, and pound,.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: ldquoApplications continue to be received for the Business Support Fund and I would encourage any eligible businesses to make sure they apply so they can receive the funding support they are entitled to.ldquoWe estimate that around , local businesses are eligible, therefore about half have already been successful in obtaining support.ldquoWe anticipate that early next week detailed information and guidance regarding the additional financial support announced by the Scottish Government will be available and as such application forms and criteria will be available from our dedicated web pages at www.scotborders.gov.uk covidbusiness.

title: girl-15-tells-people-stay-positive-short-film
story: A TEENAGER has made a short film to encourage people to be ldquopositive during the coronavirus pandemic.Emillie Jo Galbraith, , created the stop-motion video after noticing some of her friends had become unmotivated under lockdown.Emillie Jo urges viewers to adopt a can-do attitude and remain hopeful.The Biggar residenttold us: ldquoI just really wanted to help people and spread a positive message.The aspiring doctor made the video on April , using her iPhone to capture hundreds of images before editing them into a sequence and adding a voiceover.After posting the end result online, Emillie Jo was delighted to find her message quickly securing support.ldquoItrsquos gone really well, she said, reflecting on the feedback. ldquoNHS Lanarkshire have put it up on their Facebook page and it had a lot of really lovely comments.Outlining how she was inspired to craft the video in the first place, she said she had become aware of a growing negativity among her friends.She said: ldquoThey saw this time asthey were trapped and stuck inside and they were unmotivated to get up out of bed and make their day count so I wanted to help them.ldquoI wanted to help brighten up their day and help them see that this time isnrsquot just a negative time and that there is positivity, there always is - it can sometimes be dficult to see, but it is there.Emillie Jo revealed that she places a high value on looking after mental health, adding: ldquoWe need positivity, we need to be resilient.She said: ldquoLike I said in my video, future generations will be looking back at us as not the negative bunch, but the resilient people who got through one of the most challenging times.Emillie Jos video can be watched through this link.

title: borders-college-staff-create-visors-key-workers
story: STAFF at Borders College are supporting frontline workers by making face shields.Assistant principal Davie Lowe and lecturer Mark Catto took home the colleges D printers so they could create headbands and attach acetate shields.The visors are being distributed to care homes by Scottish Borders Council during the coronavirus pandemic.Mr Lowe said: ldquoIrsquod seen that other schools and colleges were utilising their D printers for this, so we decided that, as wersquove got D printers, we could use them.ldquoOur colleague Paul Watson, from Eyemouth High School, shared an approved open-source programme for creating the headband, which allowed us to get these into production.ldquoBetween Mark and myself, we hope to produce over  face shields a week.Last Friday , at the end of their first week making the visors, the pair had produced .The D printers take up to one hour to build up the layers of plastic that create the headband. The acetate screens then attached are made using lamination pouches.Mr Lowe said: ldquoThe process is fairly straightforward and, in fact, my we Yvonne is keeping the production going when I am working in the other room.The shields act as a physical barrier to protect health care workersrsquo faces, and D printer owners around the world are uniting to create an international network of DIY manufacturing.Mr Catto, a construction and STEM lecturer, said: "As my we works at the Borders General Hospital, I can see first-hand the impact this virus is having.ldquoAny small way that can support the NHS at this time can only be beneficial.ldquoI have also got my eight-year-old son Alasdair helping out with the D printing and assembly of the visors.

title: galashiels-town-band-mark-date-declaration-night
story: MUSICIANS gave a socially-distanced performance on their doorsteps to mark what would have been the Declaration Night for the Braw Lads Gathering.Despite the official event being cancelled, members of Galashiels Town Band decided they should still honour the occasion.Band chairman Neal Wade said: "We thought we should do this for morale ndash we are the towns band, after all."Last Friday , a total of  band members lted the towns spirits with their rendition, played from inidual gardens and doorsteps.The tune was re-written, said Mr Wade, to allow musicians of all ages to participate.Chairman of the Braw Lads Gathering Craig Whitehead said: "I would like to personally thank the Galashiels Town Band for playing inidually from their homes on Friday night at pm."It was a super idea and the compilation of the video was very special indeed."Unfortunately we had to cancel this years Gathering due to the COVID- situation, but itrsquos great to see support like this towards the Braw Ladsrsquo Gathering."We will continue to keep our Facebook and Twitter accounts up to date over the next few months with #throwbackthursday."The bands musical director is now providing online lessons, with plans in place for the group to record their own parts to a tune and combine them later.Mr Wade added: "Its not the year we expected, but you cant keep the band down ndash Im very proud of them. Next year will be fantastic."To watch the bands performance from Declaration Night, you can click here.

title: borders-professor-moots-return-national-service
story: A BORDERS professor has asked the UK Government to consider bringing back National Service.In an article published this week by The Times, military historian Sir Hew Strachan, Lord-Lieutenant of Tweeddale, was quoted from his report issued to the Ministry of Defence.In his report, Sir Hew said that bringing back National Service, which was phased out in , could help people better discuss the role of the military in the UK.The report also suggests that the military is expressed more like "a mythologised memory of the Second World War than an appreciation of armed conflict as it is experienced and conducted today.Tweeddale MP David Mundell told this newspaperhe is unsure about the idea of reinstating National Service, a programme which meant men aged - had to serve in one of the armed forces for  months.Mr Mundell said: ldquoWe already have a form of National Service emerging with the many thousands of public-spirited people coming forward to volunteer to help with the response to coronavirus.ldquoThe contribution in Tweeddale has been exceptional and that has been the case in many parts of Scotland and across the UK.ldquoMany young people have been doing their bit. We already have an lsquoarmyrsquo of volunteers and they are doing a fantastic job.ldquoIrsquom not sure we need to bring back National Service in the current circumstances. It could end up a bit of a distraction ldquoWe have very professional armed forces, who are currently doing a great deal to help, not all in the public domain."They are achieving a huge amount, particularly on the logistics front and supporting the expanded testing programme.Sir Hews report was commissioned by the Ministry of Defences development, concepts and doctrine centre , a ministry think-tank, in .

title: family-find-121-year-old-copy-borders-newspaper
story: A COUPLE have expressed their amazement at finding a -year-old copy of a local newspaper while renovating a historic Peebles building.Shona Haslam and her husband Marc purchased the old Peebles Courthouse in .But they were staggered when they discovered a perfectly preserved  edition of the Peebles News.Scottish Borders Council leader Mrs Haslam said: ldquoIt is a fantastic piece of local history and will definitely be finding a special place when the building is finally renovated.Justice was delivered from the former sherf court on the High Street for  years before its closure in .The Haslams bought the property three years ago and it will eventually become their family home, as well as holiday accommodation.The family were astonished when they found the old newspaper, costing one half-penny, dated February , .Mrs Haslam told us: ldquoI know DIY is a favourite lockdown activity for many, and in the Courthouse we have our fair share."While we were cleaning out, in one of the many boxes that we found when we moved in, I discovered this absolute gem of a Peebles Newsfrom ."She added: ldquoWhat always amazes me is how many of the names are still recognisable as well-kent within the town. You only need to look at the names of the committee of the March Riders meeting to see so many familiar surnames."The newspapers content included:A notice from the Town Clerk WM Buchan, requesting householders not to put paper in their ash buckets daily.Details of the Peebles Choral Society Annual ConcertAn auction sale of plants and shrubs in James Smithrsquos Auction Rooms at  and  Northgate, PeeblesAdverts for umbrella repairs by Turnbullrsquos John Dougallrsquos watchmaker, jeweller, cycle agent and optician John Greenrsquos winter clothing WM Weatherston  Son, Saddlers and Harness Makers Walter Mitchellrsquos Bootmaker, NorthgateHouses for sale ndash Cottages at Walkershaugh, Damdale, and Wemyss PlaceSports reports from Leithen Rovers, Peebles Rangers, Peebles Rovers, Walkerburn ThistleAn article detailing a public meeting of the Peebles March Riding which was presided over by Provost Ballantyne in the Town HallAn annual meeting of the Peebles Brass Band in the Masonic Hall where Chairman Mr J A Kerr presided over a most ldquomeagre attendance of the public, which he took as a sign that the public had no fault to find with their management

title: teacher-urges-athletes-run-virtual-three-bridges-races
story: DESPITE the annual Three Bridges Races in Peebles being cancelled this year, families are being asked to go the distance for the NHS.Due to coronavirus-related restrictions, the whistle was blown on the mass event which had been due to take place on Sunday.However, Peebles PE teacher Richard Edge has found a way over that hurdle and says people can still take part.He explained: ldquoDue to the current situation and the subsequent cancellation of numerous sporting events, I have no doubt that many of our young athletes will be missing a little bit of competition."I would like to invite anyone to run the equivalent distance of the infamous lsquoThree Bridges Racersquo which is . miles .k.Entry is free but competitors are being invited to make a donation through a fundraising page for the NHS.The Priorsford Primary teacher says the route does not have to cover the bridges.ldquoIn fact I would only suggest running this routevery early in the morning or later in the evening," he said."Itrsquos very important that you adhere to the current social distancing guidelines.ldquoItrsquos quite good fun working out a route, so work together with older family members and create one that suits you."This year, however, there will not be any gold medals being doled out. ldquoThe winner will receive absolutely nothing ndash just the joy of being part of the first virtual Three Bridges," said Mr Edge.Families can also take part in a team event, the teacher explained.ldquoAs we are spending longer with kids, a family run may be fun, Mr Edge said. "A group of three or more people can do a run and finish together. Your family timed run should be titled lsquo bridges virtual family runrsquo."Just as would-be competitors are being asked not to drive to their start lines, they are also being urged to obey social distancing rules when out running.Mr Edge said: ldquoBe considerate to other people by keeping a minimum of m distance at all times when passing. Runs must be completed solo, unless you are running as a family."Entrants are asked to submit their finishing times online before May .Mr Edge said: ldquoSome people will have access to a watch that will be able to time the run and will be linked to something like Strava map my run. If you do not have a watch, use a smart phone with one of the running apps open and record it that way."Once you have recorded your run, you are invited to title it lsquo bridges virtual runrsquo, take a screen shot and email it to: Gwedgerichard@glow.sch.uk, including your name and year of birth.Mr Edge added: ldquoA selfie at the finish of your run would be pretty cool. I will then try and use the information to create final results.If you would like to make a donation to the NHS, visit this website.

title: virus-test-centre-opens-galashiels-key-workers
story: KEY workers in the Borders who are self-isolating can now be tested for coronavirus in Galashiels.A centre at Netherdale car park is open from todayuntil May .The facility, run by the military, will allow key workers who are displaying symptoms to be tested for the virus, with family members also eligiblethey live under the same roof.Scottish Borders Councilsays the site poses no threat to the public, adding that all equipment will be removed at the end of each day.SBC chief executive Tracey Logan said: "I am delighted that we have managed to work with partners to quickly put in place plans to provide drive-through testing for key workers in the Scottish Borders."Irsquod urge any key worker who is self isolating, either because they themselves have symptoms of COVID- or because a member of their household is, to book tests."Testing is open to four priority groups, with those in Priority Group One already having access to NHS testing facilities.Priority Group Two includes "essential workers in critical national infrastructure fundamental for safety and security, and le-line services" Priority Group Three includes "staff directly involved in delivering other essential services" and Priority Group Four is for "staff involved in volunteering, or in nationally or locally signicant industry important to economic sustainability and growth".Key workers should visit this websiteto book their slot at the centre, which has been set up to support the UK Governments testing programme.

title: holiday-refunds---rights-get-money-back
story: Banks nationwide have blocked "billions of pounds" worth of refunds for holidays cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak.It is estimated that the public is collectively owed about pound billion from travel firms.Forced instead to turn to their banks for help, many customers have now been told they are not eligible for a refund.Heres what you need to know.Why arenrsquot travel firms giving refunds Consumer watchdog Which  recently revealed that  of the UKrsquos largest airlines and travel firms are illegally withholding refunds which should be paid to customers within  days.Instead, most customers have been offered vouchers or credit notes, with many complaining that they have been unable to claim a refund online, or get through to customer services on the phone to ask for their money back.Should I ask my bank for a refund Customers who have been refused a refund by travel firms and paid for their trip using a credit card can claim the money back from their provider under Section  of the Consumer Rights Act.Credit card providers are jointly liable with the retailer or trader for any breach of contract for misrepresentation, providing the value is more than pound and less than pound,.However, Which  has warned that some credit card customers have been told by their provider that theyre not eligible for a refund through the scheme.Others have been informed that their claim wonrsquot be processed until they have tried to claim the cash from the travel firm first, even though this is not a legal requirement.Customers are also able to claim through a process known as chargeback, which allows a transaction to be reversedyou are unable to resolve a dispute, including services not delivered.This covers all card payments and is a process agreed between financial institutions and the relevant card scheme, such as Mastercard and Visa.What are Mastercard and Visarsquos chargeback rights Mastercard said there is a chargeback right where firms have cancelled goods or services, even where this is due to government restrictions, insolvency or other exceptional circumstances.It is also validthe cardholder doesnrsquot wish to accept the firmrsquos offer to rebook or claim a voucher, but the issue should first be attempted to be resolved with the firm.Visarsquos guidance also states that firms should process a refund promptlycustomers decline a credit note or voucher, and cardholders do have a right to complain when goods or services are not provided.However, Visa does make an exception where firms have failed to provide a service due to a government-imposed travel ban, stating that this ldquosupersedes Visa rules on dispute rights.For this reason, Mastercard customers are likely to be more successful when making chargeback claims for coronavirus-related cancellations.If flights are cancelled due to closed borders, customers will still have a dispute right under both Mastercard and Visa, as EU-wide rules around refunds override the government travel ban, according to Which .Which banks will refund under Section  and chargeback Banks have said that they will assess each case inidually when it comes to refunds from firms only offering credit notes or rebooking a cancelled trip.This is what the major banks told Which  about issuing refunds:Where a provider has not met their legal obligations to the customer, Barclays will consider both chargeback and Section  claims, provided the relevant criteria are met.HSBC, including First Directand MS Bank, will allow a chargeback or Section  claim to be made for goods or services not received, but customers are encouraged to contact their airline first.Lloyds Group, including Halaxand Bank of Scotlandsay thata refund is not offered by the travel firm and a customer has proof of this, the bank can pursue a disputed transaction claim under scheme rules.Bankrsquos position is that every chargeback and dispute is dferent, and each claim will need to be assessed on a case-by-case basis with the customer to work out the best solution.Nationwidealso says each case will be looked at on a case-by-case basis because it depends on the type of good services being purchased and what the terms of the agreement are with the merchant.Similarly, RBS, including Natwestand Ulster Bank, said cases would be considered on an inidual basis.If a claim made with the merchant in the first instance is not satisfactory, customers can contact Santanderto raise a claim.,params: .pushWhere the merchant has offered the chance to rebook for free and or provide vouchers and the customer is not satisfied with this then Starling Banksays it would initiate a chargeback.If a merchant is not offering a refund, or are asking customers to contact their card issuers to process a refund, Tesco Bankcustomers can raise a dispute.The Co-operative Banksays thatcustomers tried to resolve the issue with the merchant first but there was no refund or resolution, the bank would look at each case inidually to verya dispute chargeback right existed. If a chargeback right existed but the cardholder accepted a credit voucher, this would not affect the cardholderrsquos original dispute rights. The bank would also not reject a Section  claim outright in these circumstances.If customers are offered a voucher or a chance to rebook, TSBwould typically accept the claims and each case will be considered inidually.If the customer is unhappy with the solution offered by the merchant, Virgin Moneywould consider the terms and conditions. If the alternative arrangements are not covered, a chargeback would normally be successful. Section  claims will be considered on a case-by-case basis.

title: 5g-mast-proposed-galashiels-council-land
story: PLANS for a G mast in Galashiels have been lodged with Scottish Borders Council .The applicationwould see the .-metresteel pole placed on the verge of the townrsquos King Street, on land owned by the council.Residents are now able to submit their views on the proposal, put forward by Harlequin Group on behalf of EE Ltd.Galashielscouncillor Euan Jardine said: "I believe it is important for our local economy that we are on level terms with other towns throughout the country in regards to G provision."It will also have some positive aspects for recreational usage and help to usher in advancements in technology that will change a lot of how we go about our daily lives."Mr Jardine added that he had not been approached by any residents about the application.Meanwhile, his ward colleagueHarry Scott told the Border he was not aware of the plans.Mr Scott said: "I would need to study the application and the circumstances around it before coming to any conclusions."The application, ref   C, can be viewed on the council website.

title: borders-homes-can-book-virtual-visit-auctioneer-bonhams
story: BORDERS residents have the chance to invite a world-famous auctioneer to look round their homes this week.Bonhams is delivering a free valuation service through video conferencing apps.And this week, households in the Borders are under the spotlight, with residents being asked to dig out paintings, jewellery, furniture and collectables.Bonhams Scotland managing director Charles Graham-Campbell said: "Wersquore trying to adapt and do these valuations in a way thatrsquos safe for everybody.Appointments are available from Tuesday until Thursday , am to pm.Items that can be assessed include paintings, silver, jewellery, ceramics, glass, clocks, works of art, furniture, Asian items, and collectables such as whisky.Mr Graham-Campbell, , said: ldquoWersquove always provided valuations where people have sent in photographs but we havenrsquot actually done a Zoom, Teams or WhatsApp virtual meeting ndash a video going round a house looking at objects.ldquoSo this is something new, itrsquos the antique world adapting to the situation we currently find ourselves in. Like other places, we are shut down at the moment."We canrsquot do a lot of work, but wersquore happy to try and help people where we can.Mr Graham-Campbell said it is more useful to see the house via video than to have photographs sent to the company.He said: ldquoWersquore quite used to handling photographs and working from photographs as a profession."It is always best to handle things, and there is always a caveat that the valuation is subject to further research.ldquoBut when we ask people to send in a photograph, they send in a photo of what they think is valuable, and what they think is a family heirloom."But so often when we go to a house, wersquore asked to go and look at a piece of furniture, for example, but actually itrsquos a small Chinese vase, sitting inside a cabinet, thatrsquos the valuable little item and theyrsquoll make more money than all the furniture put together. And they wonrsquot have necessarily known that.Even during the COVID- crisis, valuations continue to be required, Mr Graham-Campbell said.ldquoPeople take over something or inherit it and suddenly need an accurate insurance valuation and we can again have a look round and provide a stopgap valuation, until the times when we can do things in the correct manner, said Mr Graham-Campbell.ldquoThings that are being valued for a business need to be done to comply with their insurance every five years or something."Items need to be valued either for insurance or for probate, or executry purposes."Much of Bonhamsrsquo business is auctioneering, which has also had to be put on hold.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWith the situation as it is now, there are some people wanting to raise a sum of money and theyrsquove maybe invested in antiques in the past and theyrsquore using that as part of their pension fund."Theyrsquove maybe spent more on buying some paintings than putting into a pension fund and then theyrsquore wanting to realise those assets just to live or give something to their children who are having a hard time and not working at the moment.Scottish auctions normally take place at the Bonhams venue in Queen Street, Edinburgh, and these will also now be taking place online.Mr Graham-Campbell said: ldquoWersquore starting to do virtual auctions ndash wersquove done online auctions in the past, so wersquore quite used to doing them, but wersquore starting to work out how we can do more of them and then wersquore going to do a live auction behind closed doors."Wersquore hopefully going to be able to do that with maybe a live auctioneer and telephone bidders working from home and a clerk at a safe distance away."But the actual venue will be shut to the general public, and the public will be at home bidding away on their computers.ldquoThere are ways that we can work in a safe manner in the near future.To book a virtual valuation appointment, or for more information, email contactvaluations.scotland@bonhams or call Charles Graham-Campbell on

title: hundreds-meals-head-hardship
story: As well as providing food to children who would usually get free school meals, cooked meals are being delivered to other families in need.A number of items have been donated by local businesses and members of the community, with meals being cooked by volunteers in the Port Seton Centre.Bryan Hickman, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council chair, said: ldquoWersquove been delivering over  things a day to the community ndash itrsquos been a big effort in every part. added: ldquoMost of those we have been delivering to have been nominated by other people.ldquoTherersquos about  or  families that receive free school meals in the area and around  OAPs, so itrsquos a
