title: world-boxing-champion-josh-taylor-delivers-easter-eggs-east-lothian-youngsters
story: Taylor, the current IBF and WBA super lightweight champion, joined forces with the Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes organisation who were delivering the chocolate treats to families in East Lothian.The kind-hearted pugilist, , surprised scores of children in Prestonpans, Cockenzie and Port Seton when he and his furry friend knocked on their door to hand over the free eggs.The charity took to social media to thank the undefeated boxing champ and to reveal local police officers also got in on the act with the boxer.Their message read: ldquoA huge thank you to Josh Taylor for helping us deliver Easter Eggs to the children in our community today.ldquoLots of very excited children and it was lovely to see so many smiling faces. We even got stopped by the police and thought we were in trouble but they just wanted a photo with us. Lol.ldquoSorry we could not get to every street, we did our best.One delighted customer said: ldquoA huge thank you for today. My husband died eight weeks ago and I have been struggling so much financially and mentally I contacted your wonderful project to get a chicken dinner box.ldquoI [also] asked for the Easter Bunny to visit as I knew it would be lovely for my kids ndash never did we expect Josh Taylor at the door.ldquoMy kids loved it and I have never seen them so excited or smile like this since their daddy died.ldquoThey spoke about it all day, especially my son who is a huge Josh fan ndash you have no idea the joy you have brought to this house today.Another mum said: ldquoMy two were over the moon with their eggs and a visit from the champ himself.And a delighted grandmother added: ldquoWell done guys ndash my grandson just had a visit and the look on his wee face says it all. Thank you from a grateful gran.The Sunday Fresh Chicken Dinner Boxes charity provides fresh chicken meals to people who are struggling financially in the East Lothian area.Taylor, from Prestonpans, unied the IBF and WBA super lightweight titles, as well as lting the World Boxing Super Seriesrsquo Muhammad Ali Trophy with victory over Regis Prograis in London last October.

title: couples-diamond-anniversary-party-hold-thanks-virus
story: Robert and Kay Mackie, of North Crescent, celebrated  years of marriage on April .They had originally planned a meal with  close friends and family at the Prestoungrange Gothenburg on April , but the dinner had to be postponed.Robert was born in Edinburgh on November , , and has lived in Prestonpans all his le, attending local primary and high schools.He worked in a garage and then as a miner, working in dferent pits until his retirement in .He is a keen golfer and a member of the Royal Musselburgh Golf Club.Kay was born in Canada on November , , but moved with her family to Carmichael, Lanark, when she was three or four years old.The pair met dancing at the Cavendish club in Edinburgh in May , and were engaged at Christmas the same year.They married a year later at Glencorse Church, near Penicuik.Kay worked in an office until she and Robert started their own family Sheila was born in  and Diana in .The family lived in Cockenzie for seven years before moving to Prestonpans. Robert and Kay have now lived in the same house for  years.Sheila explained why her parents had decided to marry on April .She said: ldquoMy mumrsquos only brother, Michael Robertson, was emigrating back to Canada and she wanted him at the wedding.ldquoThat was the only date they could get before he emigrated he moved back the week after and still lives there now. It was nothing to do with April Foolrsquos Day!The pair have three grandchildren, one great grandson and two step-great granddaughters. Sheilarsquos eldest son, Calum, was born in  and she said the new grandparents were soon taking on babysitting duties.Sheila said: ldquoTheyrsquore really family orientated and helped a lot with bringing the kids up. They would go to their house after school.With celebration plans now on hold, the family instead spent part of the morning waving to the happy couple from afar.Sheila said: ldquoWe went round in the morning and waved in the window. It was nice to see them theyrsquore celebrating so many years married.When asked their secret to a long and happy marriage, Sheila added: ldquoThey said to listen to each other and to not go to bed on an argument.

title: art-therapy-charity-teapot-trust-makes-services-available-online
story: The Teapot Trust has made its one-to-one art therapy available via video conferencing and put in place new protocols for online safety.This will ensure that children and young people living with chronic conditions, who are experiencing heightened anxiety in these unprecedented times, wonrsquot miss out on the regular therapy they rely on.Delivering art therapy online is something the charity was already exploring as a means of reaching those in rural locations but coronavirus accelerated those plans.Teapot trustee Dr Simon Hackett recently secured funding from the Carnegie Trust to research this topic.The charityrsquos art therapists can now be involved in the research to assess the impact of this new work.In addition to online therapy, and to keep children creatively occupied at home, a suite of resources developed by Teapot Trust will soon be available on its website. Fun activities, task sheets and video clips will be available.Teapot Trust CEO Sarah Randell said: ldquoIrsquom so proud of our team of art therapists and core staff who together have quickly transformed the way we deliver art therapy. Theyrsquove created a secure online world so that children donrsquot miss out on an important part of their lives which helps them cope better with the impact of their conditions.ldquoGiven that many fundraising events have been cancelled or postponed, a donation to Teapot Trust, no matter how small, will help us to ensure that we can continue supporting children and young people remotely at this challenging time.ldquoWersquod also love to hear from anyone keen to fundraise in new and creative wayshellip online tea party, anyone The Teapot Trust, based at Stuart House, Eskmills Park, provides a programme of art therapy in hospitals to support children and young people with chronic conditions and their families.The charity, which celebrates its th anniversary this year, was founded by Laura and John Young, of Gullane, after their daughter Verity died from cancer in November .Verity also suffered lupus and had spent most of her le in hospital. She had taken comfort in art as a way to escape.To donate or find out more, visit teapot-trust.org

title: volunteers-helping-throughout-musselburgh
story: The emergency efforts are being co-ordinated by Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council and Musselburgh Area Partnership as they do what they can to support the communities of Musselburgh, Wallyford, Whitecraig and Old Craighall, which have a combined population of about ,.They are working from the Resilient Musselburgh Hub, which is based at Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School.Iain Clark, area partnership chairman, said: ldquoThe support to Resilient Musselburgh from community volunteers has been fantastic and has allowed us to deliver much-needed support to those who need it most.ldquoOur volunteers have been deployed every day and are providing a much-needed and crucial service.ldquoWe now have  amazing volunteers registered and they have been deployed on a daily basis to assist in delivering lunches to the vulnerable, emergency food supplies, prescriptions and leafleting targeted areas of the community.ldquoVolunteers are contacted as available and attend at the hub, where their delivery is brought out to them."ldquoThey have also been attending ious chemists to uplt and deliver prescriptions.ldquoThey must be on the Resilient Musselburgh register to be deployed as this provides public liability insurance cover.ldquoWe have funded the emergency food provision through the purchase of supplies which have been made into emergency packs which include food and items for personal hygiene. We also maintain a stock of sanitary products and hearing aid batteries.ldquoDuring the weekend period, when the hub is not open, a quantity of emergency food provision is relocated to allow provision over the weekendurgently required.The team has delivered  five-day lunch packs to families in the community, and volunteers in Whitecraig have also distributed  meals, supplied by local restaurant the Mercat Grill.Mr Clark said: ldquoMusselburgh Area Partnership has been allocated pound, by East Lothian Council from the Scottish Governmentrsquos Food Fund.ldquoWe are working with Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council to focus these new funds to provide the most positive impact we can to those who need our support. We are also supporting Wallyford and Whitecraig Community Councils as we look towards a co-ordinated effort during these very dficult times for many.Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council has allocated pound, and a further pound has been donated by Wallyford Community Council to help fund the initiative.Mr Clark said: ldquoWe are currently managing all the calls that come via our dedicated number, co-ordinating the registration and deployment of all volunteers and maintaining an action database of all requirements to ensure a log of what needs done and when it has been completed.ldquoIn addition, we are dealing with all the elements of the referral forms from the East Lothian Council Contact Centre that require action from Resilient Musselburgh. Given the current social distancing requirements, the co-ordination is being undertaken remotely via shared online access.ldquoWe are still looking to build on our pool of volunteers to ensure sustainability, soyou know of anyone who would be interested in supporting us then they can register using the following link and scrolling down to Resilient Musselburgh Covid-: eastlothian.gov.uk musselburghapAlister Hadden, chair of Wallyford Community Council, and Shona Bennett, chair of Whitecraig Community Council, highlighted the teamrsquos ldquoamazing volunteers, saying they had nothing but ldquoadmiration and praise for them.The hub has priority access to Tesco Musselburgh to buy emergency food supplies when necessary.Tesco has donated pound in vouchers and provides a free weekly supply of fresh fruit to support lunch provision for vulnerable people.Resilient Musselburgh has been nominated by the Pinkie Farm Shop for a pound grant from its charity MADL .For help contact the Community Resilience phone line:  .

title: dunbear-bit-ahead-celebrity-bbc-programme
story: The five-metre high DunBear sculpture, created by renowned Scottish artist, Andy Scott, the man behind the lsquoKelpiesrsquo, will don the virtual eye patch, which will be promoted via social media, as a means to encourage people to give to the cause.The programme, which takes place this eveningat pm, is raising funds for local projects across the UK during the coronavirus pandemic.Stars such as Sir Lenny Henry, Davina McCall and Gary Barlow will take part in the event on BBC, with DunBear doing his bit with a Pudsey-style eyepatch.Iniduals are also being encouraged to contribute to Dunbar charity, The Ridge.The good cause, recognised for its outstanding work with young people, has joined forces with Dunbarrsquos community council as it shts its focus to providing practical support for those of all ages adversely affected by Covid-.Jointly managed funds are already making a dference by providing food, clothes, toys and books.A hot meals service is underway and The Ridge will direct and support people to debt advice services, mental health services and counselling.Small grants are available to groups, charities or iniduals where such a grant will help people in crisis.Pippa Swan, chairwoman of Dunbar Community Council, praised The Ridgersquos work and said: ldquoTheir community work places them in the very best position to take a lead in helping iniduals and families during the Covid- crisis and beyond and any funds raised will be directed fully to those in most need of help.The sculpture celebrates one of Dunbarrsquos most famous sons, John Muir, born on Tuesday this week in , who is credited with playing a key role in the development of Americarsquos national parks.It forms part of the mixed-use Hallhill development, which has already delivered sports facilities,  acres of community woodland together with more than , homes, either built or under construction.To support The Ridge go to paypal.me The RidgeDunbar locale. xen_GB

title: tims-tales-site-tea-riffic-well
story: A WHILE back I came across a reference to the ldquoBickers Well in Musselburgh.I hadnrsquot heard of this before so I looked into it.I found a little information about it.It was located in Dam Brae and was said to contain water with special qualities that helped make a perfect pot of tea.There is little explanation as to what exactly these qualities were, but it seems to have been widely believed and accepted in the past.Tea, of course, became popular in Scotland, and by the th century it had become an important accompaniment to the often mundane diet of working class people, providing a refreshing non-alcoholic alternative to beer.For the poor, tea drinking wasnrsquot linked to formal social rituals as it was with the upper classes.Tea was the drink of the working class as they worked.So, a well in the heart of the town which was believed to supply good tea making water will have been a busy and popular place.Many people, likely mostly women, would have congregated around the well.In the OS name book from the s, it was clearly recorded that the well was listed as the ldquoVickerrsquos Well, but then goes on to state that ldquono person in the locality knows it by that name.Everyone called it ldquothe bickers well.Perhaps this was a result of local dialect changing the name over time.But Paul Bennet, in his interesting website ldquoThe Northern Antiquarian says ldquothere is the obvious possibility that the ldquobickers ndash as in chit-chat and gossip ndash related to it being where local folk simply met and chatted.Perhaps the reputation of the wellrsquos water for making quality tea also meant people from further afield considered it worthwhile to detour here, in order to make that extra special ldquoBickerrsquos Brew.One account says it was once surrounded by old trees.All of this conjures an image of an important social meeting place, with people meeting under the shade of old trees, exchanging views and information and having a good blether while they wait their turn to draw water from the celebrated well.Was the belief in the goodness of the water rooted in some older tradition Perhaps it was a revered holy well, as some have suggested It seems to have been associated with the vicarage of St Michaels nearby, which roots the well in Musselburghrsquos ancient past, and gives a reason for the name Vicarrsquos Well.The well was replaced by a pump sometime in the nineteenth century, and then was blocked up, and became forgotten.When Irsquod discovered all this I set out to find the location of the well to seethere was still any evidence of it.Dam Brae is now named Kilwinning Place and I studied a nineteenth century map which marked the exact location of the well, then compared it to a modern one and set out on my quest.I found the location. Irsquom sure of it, and took a photo.But there wasnrsquot really anything of much interest to see other than a slab on the ground where I believe the well once stood.It seemed so forgotten, and put me in a melancholy mood for a moment.I reflected on the way something that had been a tradition for so long, and such a part of many peoplersquos lives can just vanish, and be utterly forgotten.I know it was just a well and so might not seem important.But it was a meeting place for ordinary people for generations.The simple shared routines and places in our lives are often the ones we remember with nostalgia.We donrsquot think of them as history or worthy of recording until all memory has gone, and itrsquos too late.I thought about this as we were going on our local family walk this week.I suppose we all know we are living through a time that will be recorded by history.But when all this is over, and things are back to ldquonormal what simple things will you, and your family, remember from this time and what will you want remembered For me, this includes seeing the Greenhills carpeted with wildflowers for the first time that I can remember, watching children cycle on empty streets and deserted car parks, and queuing in shops, keeping our physical distance while also trying to stay social.For sure the toilet roll panic will be part of history.But all of us will have special moments and places that connect to the emotions of this time.There will be stories of peoplersquos wonderful community spirit, what it felt like to be confined in the house for weeks, and how we entertained ourselves.We are all historians of our own time, and we should find ways to record and remember the simple, but important, things we have felt and encountered during this time of crisis.Because memory fades, and as the fate of the Bickers Well shows,memories are not recorded or stories of them not told, they will be forgotten.And so this was why I decided to re-visit the story of the Bickers Well for my column this week.It may have originally seemed there was not much to tell about it.Yet once there was.But the memories and the stories connected to it seemed so simple and obvious at the time that nobody really thought them important enough to record or keep treasured.Now all that remains of those stories is a slab on the pavement.The technology we have makes it easier now to share and record our lives.So letrsquos use it to consciously be historians and storytellers of this dficult time to capture images and feelings, the happenings that may today seem too simple and commonplace to record, but in future will be a fascinating insight to our lives in this historic event.For me, that is the lesson of the Bickers Well.

title: winton-brewery-takes-countys-micropub
story: Steve Holligan and David Mackinnon, from Winton Brewery, stepped behind the bar at Dunbarrsquos Station Yard Micropub at the beginning of the month.Currently, the duo are only allowed to sell off-sales, due to the coronavirus lockdown preventing customers from entering the pub, but they were looking forward to once again welcoming people inside as soon as possible.Steve said: ldquoWersquove been looking for a while to find something like this.ldquoThe Station Yard is unbelievable.ldquoWe looked in Haddington, we looked in Gullane and we wanted to stay in East Lothian, where we are from and where the brewery is based.ldquoIt was one of those things where you were scrolling through Facebook and this popped up.ldquoIt was too good an opportunity and we got in touch with Gerard McPhillips [who had created the pub alongside his late business partner David McGee] and had a really good meeting with him. We have had a beer in the pub before and been in a few times and knew David really well.ldquoWe are trying to carry it on in his memory and Gerardrsquos good faith.The former station lodge was transformed into East Lothianrsquos first micropub and opened its doors at the beginning of December .Gerard felt he was leaving the business in safe hands and said: ldquoIt does not feel like two years.ldquoIt has been quite a rollercoaster of a ride and it was very exciting at the start. Unfortunately, David got ill within four months of opening and the gloss came off it.David McGee was forced to step aside in the spring of March  after being diagnosed brain cancer. He died in October last year.Gerard added: ldquoWe achieved what we wanted to achieve and we are pretty confident Winton Brewery will take it forward in the same vein.ldquoI absolutely feel that it has been left in good hands, and that was a big driver for accepting their bid because we did feel it would be in safe hands.Steve and David, who are originally from Haddington, have limited changes planned for the pub, which will feature beers from Winton Breweryrsquos range.It was while sampling a home brew in Steversquos kitchen in Pencaitland that the friends decided to form their own brewery six years ago.Now, they have four distinct beers: Peelywally, a zesty and citrusy IPA Barry Swally, a hoppy and aromatic APA Oh Ya Bassa, a peach and raspberry sour beer and Stooty Fruit, a raspberry oatmeal stout.Forty-one-year-old Steve felt the Micropub site was a fitting bookend, given the breweryrsquos base in West Barns, alongside the hugely successful Thistly Cross Cider.Originally, the Station Yard, which is owned by Network Rail, was the stationmasterrsquos house, which he shared with his we and seven children.Between  and  the building and yard were used by T.Foggo  Son coal merchants and since  the building had a iety of uses, including as a cafeacute and offices.

title: sir-hew-dalrymple-appointed-new-deputy-lieutenant
story: Sir Hew Dalrymple, of Blackdykes Farm, near North Berwick, whose family own the Bass Rock and have been active in East Lothian le for more than  years, takes on the role.His late father, Sir Hew Hamilton-Dalrymple, who died in December  at the age of , was a former Lord Lieutenant of East Lothian.Lord Lieutenants are employed by the Queen and carry out a range of duties in their counties, aided by their deputies.Sir Hew is a successful businessman involved in a wide range of companies as a business consultant, mentor and marketing adviser.He has roles in a number of North Berwick groups and organisations, and also runs the family property and farming company, through which he was involved in the setting up of Leuchie House as a national respite centre as landlord and adviser.Sir Hew was also a founding trustee of the Scottish Seabird Centre and is president of North Berwick RNLI and North Berwick Yacht Club.Michael Williams, East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant, said: ldquoI am very pleased to welcome Sir Hew as a Deputy Lieutenant for East Lothian, as he brings with him an invaluable knowledge of community and commercial le across our county.ldquoIt is also particularly appropriate as his late father also served as a Deputy Lieutenant before becoming East Lothianrsquos Lord Lieutenant for  years.

title: developer-help-cover-extension-west-barns-primary-school
story: West Barns Primary School currently has four classrooms and a temporary nursery housing a single classroom.However, that could all change with an extension being proposed by East Lothian Council.An East Lothian Council spokeswoman said: ldquoWe have submitted a planning application to expand the nursery space at West Barns Primary School and provide additional facilities for the school.ldquoThe proposals would see the existing nursery temporary unit replaced with a larger nursery, as well providing the school with a new library and an additional classroom for primary one.ldquoWe have secured developer contributions from CALA Homes for the classroom works at West Barns and funds will also be received from the Scottish Governmentrsquos  grant for the nursery expansion.ldquopound.m has been set aside in our five-year capital programme for the project.CALA Homes have planning permission for nearly  homes to the east of the primary school, off Edinburgh Road.Plans for the school extension are currently with the local authorityrsquos planning department.

title: plans-revamp-lochend-lodge-houses
story: Plans to revamp Lochend Lodge, Dunbar, at the junction of Lochend Road and Spott Road, and to create four houses on land surrounding it are being weighed up by East Lothian Council.Two separate applications ndash one to transform the existing building and the other utilising the surrounding ground ndash have been submitted to the local authorityrsquos planning department for determination.Edinburgh-based New Homes for Le, which is behind the proposals, outlined the need for attention to be given to Lochend Lodge.A design statement said: ldquoThe lodge has been extended over the years in a haphazard manner and is now in need of a complete refurbishment and remodelling to make it suitable for modern living standards, to restore its appearance and to give it a viable le for the future.Lochend Lodge is the East Lodge of the former Lochend Estate.Lochend House was built in  but was subsequently largely destroyed by fire in .The developer plans to retain ldquothe core historic lodge building and remove later extensions, with a view to ldquorestore a run-down and sub-standard two-bedroom house and provide a desirable three-bedroom modern house.The four new properties would be built to the south and west of the existing lodge.Access to the new two-storey homes would come from Lochend Road.The loss of trees on the site has been described as ldquounavoidable, with each of the proposed new homes having four upstairs bedrooms, with a kitchen and sitting area downstairs.The design statement said: ldquoThe proposed development will provide more housing in an established residential area.ldquoIt will also allow the retention and renovation of the historic Lochend Lodge, which is in a rundown condition and would have been lostthe site had been redeveloped as flats as originally proposed.ldquoWhile the loss of trees is regrettable, it is considered that the impact of the proposals are generally positive and help to consolidate this corner of an established residential area, reducing the demand for new peripheral development.

title: boys-birthday-bagpipe-tunes-bring-smile-kids-faces
story: Sam Johnston, , of Tweedie Place, North Berwick, has been playing lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo on his bagpipes for other young residents in the Walker Homes Glen Ora development.Law Primary School P pupil Sam, who plays for Preston Lodge Pipe Band, is helping children with birthdays celebrate their special day despite lockdown.It started when one mum, Fee Andrews, posted on a neighbourhood Facebook group asking for people to hang out of their windows and sing lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo to her son Brodie.Samrsquos mum Fiona suggested that he could play the bagpipes and, after playing for four-year-old Brodie, who described the experience as ldquogood, Sam has been inundated with requests.In keeping with social distancing guidelines, Sam plays the tune by his front door, with neighbours welcome to stand on the pavement and sing along.Fiona said: ldquoHe has been practising in the garden every day, and is doing his lessons online.ldquoHersquos doing something good for his community ndash giving his pipes a blow and doing something nice forthe kids that are stuck inside.ldquoI am really proud of him. He doesnrsquot like standing up in front of people so it is good he is putting himself out there when things are tough.ldquoWe are a family of pipers ndash Samrsquos papa and two of his uncles are pipers.ldquoItrsquos a family tradition to play the pipes on someonersquos birthday when the cake comes in. Itrsquos so nice that he is sharing that tradition with the kids.ldquoOne girl was too shy to stand at the door so Sam stood in the back garden and piped for her ndash she could hear it from her house.ldquoItrsquos something a bit fun to do and helps brighten their day. Itrsquos so uplting and makes people feel better we just thought it would be a wee bit of fun.ldquoSamrsquos birthday was April  so he knows how it feels.ldquoI donrsquot think he understands how big it is hersquos making people smile.Fiona added: ldquoIrsquove met more neighbours in the past few weeks than the past year of living here.Fee said: ldquoItrsquos a really lovely thing that he is doing and hersquos such a nice boy as well.ldquoBrodie kept saying, lsquoMum is that for me, is that for mersquo ldquoItrsquos brought the community closer together. When it was Samrsquos birthday, a few people came out to sing for him.At the beginning of the month Sam also played for Josie Wheatley, who was celebrating her seventh birthday. With her birthday party cancelled, and unable to celebrate with friends and family, Josie was delighted to have Sam play his bagpipes for her.Josiersquos mum Emma said: ldquoJosie said she felt happy and amazing after being piped for and being sung to by all the neighbours. It really made her feel special. She phoned all of her friends and family to tell them about her special day. It really made her feel like she had a great birthday.ldquoWhen she heard it [the music] she was so over the moon.ldquoDuring such worrying times, Sam brings a smile to the childrenrsquos faces.ldquoI just think someone who is , to put themselves out there and to make these young people feel so special is such an amazing thing to do.ldquoItrsquos so nice to see a young lad use his skills to bring happiness to children on their birthdays.

title: learning-lockdown-can-tough-council-admits
story: Lesley Brown, East Lothianrsquos chief education officer, encouraged such families, while agreeing it was not easy.She said: ldquoWith this being a dficult time, itrsquos important to recognise that we do not expect children and young people to always follow a typical school day, especially when parents are sometimes having to juggle other tasks such as looking after others or working from home.ldquoLearning can be carried out in a flexible way to suit a child familyrsquos inidual circumstances and,you have any questions about this or the best approach to take, please do not hesitate to contact your school.ldquoOur school staff will continue to embrace a flexible creative approach to learning and teaching, where possible maximising the use of digital technology to support learning for children who are being cared for at home.ldquoTeachers will continue posting [online] learning assignment tasks for children, including active learning opportunities which they can undertake with their families.ldquoAnyone who doesnrsquot have a phone or internet access should let their school know. They will ensure you have the ability to stay in contact with school staff and receive information and support in continuing childrenrsquos learning.The Young Scot website has useful advice and information, while BBC Bitesize is a helpful learning support resource for school-aged young people.Judith Tait, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for childrenrsquos services, added: ldquoWe recognise it is a very dficult time for families and that our children will be missing their friends and the daily interaction they get from school and clubs.ldquoWe also understand the challenges of keeping children and young people engaged in learning without the structure of the school day.ldquoWhile home will be the safest place for most young people, we realise this is not necessarily the case for everyone.ldquoThatrsquos why we are highlighting a number of people or organisations who can helpanyone feels worried, upset or unsafe ndash either for themselves or, indeed, someone .The councilrsquos advice in such circumstances is: l If possible, speak to an adult you know and trust who can listen and take action to helpl Although schools are closed, staff are still available to talk to. Email your childrsquos schoolrsquos officeyou would like to speak to someonel Contact Childline about anything ndash they are there to support children. Call  .l The website cooltalk.org provides a safe space where young people can get their questions answered accurately and without judgement. They respond to questions within  hours.l The social work department is there to help and support children and young people who are at risk of harm or donrsquot feel safe at home. Call    or   .l If you or someone you know is in immediate danger call the police on .l With schools being closed, children will be spending more time online and must be protected from cyberbullying and online grooming. Net Aware and Thinkuknow can help parents or s report abuse and have lots of information to minimise risks online.Ms Tait added: ldquoSupporting and meeting the needs of all our young people, including the most vulnerable, is always a priority for the council and our partners. In these unprecedented times, this has never been more important.

title: heavy-sound-bit-put-food-table
story: Heavy Sound, based in Tranent, has joined forces with other groups, including the townrsquos Fundamental Foods, to help get food to those in need.The social enterprise is also working alongside the Edinburgh International Conference Centre .With conferences and events at the city venue cancelled due to the coronavirus outbreak, Heavy Sound is partnering them to distribute food from the EICCrsquos kitchens to vulnerable communities in and around Edinburgh.Jordan Butler, Heavy Sound CEO, said: ldquoAlthough we canrsquot deliver our usual programmes at schools, we have resources and staff who are willing to support in whatever way they can.ldquoWe were already dealing with food poverty and isolation in our communities, something that has only been exacerbated by the pandemic.ldquoLow income, mental health, complex trauma and unemployment are factors at play, and the only silver lining has been around how people and businesses like the EICC are pulling together and collaborating in new ways to make a dference.Heavy Sound usually uses music, arts and sport to work with young people from a iety of backgrounds.Last year, the social enterprise revealed plans to work alongside the Scottish Prison Serviceand Police Scotlandrsquos Violence Reduction Unit to transform an old bus into a portable community service, complete with music production equipment, a food prep kitchen and a small hairdressing space.EICC is also working alongside FareShare during the global pandemic to help vulnerable members of the community.Marshall Dallas, EICC CEO, added: ldquoWith a signicant amount of food in our kitchens that wersquore unable to use for events, the natural thing to do was to find ways of getting it to the people who need it most just now.ldquoThe work being done by FareShare across the UK and Heavy Sound in Edinburgh and East Lothian is quite staggering their teams are working tirelessly to get food to so many communities and itrsquos a real privilege to play a part in that.

title: sisters-transform-bar-musselburghs-friendliest-pub
story: Rebecca and Victoria Fowler took over The Sportsman Bar in May last year, with a view to transforming the High Street premises.The venue has signed up to Best Bar None Scotland and Rebecca, of Tranent, felt it had made a massive dference in turning the business around.She said: ldquoHaving previously worked in The Sportsman, we knew what we were taking on but also knew it was something we could make work.ldquoThe pub had a bit of a reputation. We wanted to turn it into a safe place for people to come and enjoy a night out with a bit of banter thrown in: lsquoMusselburghrsquos friendliest pub.rsquo But we knew this wouldnrsquot happen overnight.Best Bar None Scotland aims to ensure everyone can enjoy a safe night out.The national scheme, which works through a partnership between local authorities, the Scottish Government, Police Scotland, Scottish Fire and Rescue Service and other organisations, works to reduce crime, reward excellence, and raise standards of alcohol licensed premises.Rebecca added: ldquoLicensing recommended we joined lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo and we were interested straight away since we knew we needed help to make the pub work.ldquoAfter speaking to the local co-ordinator and reading through the guidelines, we decided to use the lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo checklist as a guide to show us the safety changes we had to makethe pub was going to be a success.Rebecca and Victoria, of Wallyford, had both previously worked in the pub, which is at the junction of High Street and Newbigging.Rebecca told the Courier that promoting initiatives such as Ask Angela, designed to keep people safe from sexual assault by using a codeword to identy when they are in danger or an uncomfortable situation, had helped them achieve a silver Best Bar None award.She added: ldquoWe have now eliminated all the trouble and actively promote initiatives like lsquoAsk Angelarsquo.ldquoWe even hand out lollipops at the end of busy nights to help reduce noise.ldquoWe know that when our patrons leave the pub they are still our responsibility and need to get home safely.ldquoAll our customers now know that we operate a zerotolerance policy on trouble, including drugs.ldquoSafety has to be the top priority for any pub and, by working side by side with lsquoBest Bar Nonersquo, we know we are doing all that we can to create a friendly atmosphere for everyone who comes through the door, giving them an enjoyable and a safe night out.

title: extension-planned-school-prestonpans
story: East Lothian Council wants to add two classrooms to the east side of St Gabrielrsquos RC Primary School, in Prestonpans, as more housing being built in the town is expected to increase the school roll, which is currently , including the nursery.A spokeswoman for the local authority said: ldquoWe have submitted a planning application to alter and extend St Gabrielrsquos Primary School in Prestonpans.ldquoThe proposed work includes alterations to the nursery, increasing its space by expanding into the existing primary one classroom.ldquoAn extension will create space for a new primary one classroom and provide an additional classroom.ldquoOur five-year capital programme has allocated pound.m for the works, which are required to accommodate an increase in nursery provision through the Scottish Governmentrsquos expansion of funded early learning and childcare, as well as the need for additional classroom space.ldquoIn addition, the classroom extension will receive developersrsquo contributions from Blindwells and the nursery expansion will receive funding from the Scottish Government.Plans showing the proposed changes are now with the local authorityrsquos planning department.The school, which has been extended several times over the years, first opened its doors in .Currently, it has seven open plan classrooms, with two further nursery playrooms and other facilities.The proposed works would see two new primary school classrooms, as well as an expanded nursery space with new external canopy and the existing nursery reconfigured.The design and access statement included within the planning application notes: ldquoThe completed extension will provide state-of-the-art teaching and play facilities in line with the clientrsquos brief, as well as promoting energy efficiency through its design.ldquoThe project is to reflect the standards commensurate with a modern school facility and provide a high-quality environment that will inspire both staff and young people to achieve their full potential.The plans for the school could ultimately be decided by the local authorityrsquos planning committee, with all four members of the Preston Seton Gosford ward ndash Lachlan Bruce, Neil Gilbert, Willie Innes and Fiona OrsquoDonnell ndash part of the committee.

title: cherrytrees-nursery-youngsters-spell-message
story: Cherrytrees Nursery, on Dunbarrsquos Abbey Road, have been operating as a hub for the children of key workers during Covid-.A spokeswoman for the nursery told the Courier youngsters had been busy creating two banners .She said: ldquoWe have split into two teams working one week on and one week off."Team one and team two along with the children would just like to say a big hello to all our children and families who are not with us just now and also to everyone in Dunbar!"Be Kind, Stay Safe!

title: coronavirus-tests-key-workers-families-now-eligible---book-one
story: About  million key workers - and members of their household - can now book a swab test online via the governmentrsquos website from Friday , with testing having previously only been available to health workers.Who is eligible for the test Testing has now been extended to all key workers in England with symptoms, and members of the same household who have symptoms.The move marks a huge expansion of the people eligible for testing as the government moves towards its target of , daily tests by the end of April.It also means key workers can find out whether they have coronavirus, enabling them toto workthey test negative.Health Secretary Matt Hancock announced the news at the daily Downing Street press conference on Thursday , stating: ldquoWe can make it easier, faster and simpler for any essential worker in England who needs a test to get a test.ldquoAny essential workers who need a test will be able to book an appointment on gov.uk themselves directly.ldquoThis applies for people in essential workersrsquo households too, who need a test.ldquoItrsquos all part of getting Britain back on her feet.Who is classed as a key worker This is who is classed as a key worker, according to the government:- NHS and social care staff, including:- doctors, nurses, midwives, paramedics, social workers, care workers, and other frontline health and- social care staff including volunteers- the support and specialist staff required to maintain the UKrsquos health and social care sector- those working as part of the health and social care supply chain, including producers and distributors of medicines, and medical and personal protective equipment- Essential public services staff, including:- prisons, probation, courts and tribunals staff, judiciary- religious staff- charities and workers delivering critical frontline services- those responsible for the management of the deceased- journalists and broadcasters covering coronavirus or providing public service broadcasting- Public safety and national security staff, including:- police and support staff- Ministry of Defence civilians, contractors and armed forces personnel - fire and rescue service employees ,- National Crime Agency staff, those maintaining border security, prison and probation staff and other national security roles, including those overseas- Transport workers, including:- those who keep the air, water, road and rail passenger and freight transport modes operating during the coronavirus response- those working on transport systems through which supply chains pass- Education and childcare workers, including:- support and teaching staff- social workers- specialist education professionals- Critical personnel in the production and distribution of food, drink and essential goods, including:- those involved in food production, processing, distribution, sale and delivery- those critical to the provision of other essential goods, such as medical supply chain and distribution workers, including veterinary medicine- workers critical to the continuity of essential movement of goods- Local and national government staff critical to the effective delivery of the coronavirus response, or delivering essential public services, such as the payment of benefits- Public and environmental health staff, including in government agencies and armrsquosbodies- Frontline local authority staff, including those working with vulnerable children and adults, with victims of domestic abuse, and with the homeless and rough sleepers- Utilities, communication and financial services staff, including:- staff needed for essential financial services provision - building societies and financial market infrastructure- the oil, gas, electricity and water sectors - information technology and data infrastructure sector and primary industry supplies to continue during the coronavirus response- essential staff working in the civil nuclear, chemicals, telecommunications , postal services and delivery, payments providers and waste disposal sectorsWhat does the test involve The test involves taking a swab from the nose and the back of the throat, which can be done by the person themselves, or by someone .Testing is most effective within three days of symptoms developing.How can I book a test Key workers who are self-isolating can book a test directly.There is the option to select a regional test site drive-through appointment, or home test kit.Home test kit availability will initially be limited but more will become available, but there is good availability of regional test sites, so the government advises selecting this optionyou can.Alternatively, key workers can book a test through their employer.Employers can refer key workers who are self-isolating, either because they or members of their household have coronavirus symptoms, for testing.The employer referral portal is a secure for employers to use to upload the full list of names and contact details of self-isolating key workers.If referred through this portal, key workers will receive a text message with a unique invitation code to book a test for themselves,they are symptomatic, or their symptomatic household members at a regional testing site.To obtain a login, employers of essential workers should email portalservicedesk@dhsc.gov.uk with two email addresses that will primarily be used to load essential worker contact details.Once employer details have been veried, two login credentials will be issued for the employer referral portal.

title: inspired-irene-knits-charity
story: Irene, who lives in Haddington, has spent her time in lockdown knitting twiddle muffs and aims to produce  to donate to AlzheimerScotland.The colourful muffs provide people with restless hands a distraction and can be a comfort and distraction for some.Irene, , first began producing them six months ago and has used her time at home to challenge herself with her new target.And she has launched a JustGiving page for people to support her efforts and donate to AlzheimerScotland at the same time.She said: "Like so many elderly and vulnerable people, Irsquove found the recentCoronavirus lockdown situation dficult to adjust to in numerous ways."Luckily for me, whilst nowadays Irsquom a bitunsteady on my feet, Irsquom still very keen and pretty capable of doing all sortsof crafts and so have been filling the many hours, days and weeks of socialisolation by knitting twiddle muffs."There are actually several advantages to knitting twiddle muffs. Of course, thefirst and most important benefit is to the recipients ... people with dementiaoften have restless hands and like to have something to keep their handsoccupied."A twiddle muff provides awonderful source of visual, tactile and sensory stimulation, and keeps handssnug and warm at the same time."But Irsquovefound there are also benefits for me too ndash not only is knitting keeping mephysically and mentally occupied, itrsquos also making a great dent in my enormousstock of gorgeous textured and coloured wool that Irsquove been buying and hoardingfor years ... one of my guilty pleasures!"So far Irene, who lives in Monk Muir Park, has doubled her target of pound donations on her JustGiving page which stands at pound,.She said: "WatchingCaptain Tomrsquos recent endeavours to raise such an awesome amount for the NHS hasbeen an inspiration to us all."Irene is asking everyone to support her as she carries on knitting by donating to the charity.She said: "Irsquom now delighted to be donating all the twiddle muffs Irsquom knitting toAlzheimer Scotland for distribution to those in need and Irsquove set myself atarget of knitting a total of muffs."To help motivate me Irsquom hoping that all you generous people mighthelp me raise funds for Alzheimer Scotland, which is Scotlandrsquos nationaldementia charity, whose aim is to make sure that nobody faces dementiaalone."They provide support andinformation to people with dementia, their carers and families, includingproviding a  hour freephone Dementia Helpline."Alzheimer Scotland campaigns for the rightsof people with dementia and funds vital dementia research. Please donate what you can toinspire me to keep these knitting needles clacking."To donate go to bit.ly aCOrO

title: greggs-reveal-plan-reopen-stores-across-country
story: The Newcastle-based bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.The full details of how the trial will operate have not been released.Due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday night : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonalds in talks to reopen storesIt comes after McDonalds said they were in talks about opening its , restaurants across the UK, according to reports.The burger chain could open for drive-thru and delivery orders as early as mid-May, the Irish Farmers Journal said.A spokesperson for McDonalds said: "Of course we are thinking about re-opening and having those conversations ndash but its unclear when that will be."

title: burger-king-greggs-kfc-nandos-mcdonalds-preparing-reopen-uk-stores
story: As of yesterday - heres what we know so far.GreggsGreggshaveconfirmed it islooking to reopen with a number of stores expected to reopen their doorsasearly as next week.The bakery chain said it was looking to open a small number of stores to trial how it would reopen more than , stores across the UK.Although the full details of how the trial will operate have not been released, it is believed a number ofNewcastlestores will be among the first to welcome customers back.But due to currentcoronaviruslockdown rules, it remainshighly likely that Greggs wouldoperate a takeaway service only with a limited number of staff working ateach store.Its understood that alimited number of stores could open by May , as part of a staggered plan to reopen fully once restrictions are lted.A spokesperson for Greggssaid on Sunday, April : "We want to play our part in getting the nation back up and running again so we are planning to conduct a limited trial with volunteers to explore how we can reopen our shops with new measures in place that keep our colleagues and customers as safe as we can when we re-open at scale."McDonaldsNo confirmed date has been revealed as to when McDonalds will , but work is going on behind the scenes to prepare for a small-but-steadyacross the country.Paul Pomroy, McDonaldrsquos CEO UK and Ireland said on Tuesday, April :"In March, we took the decision to temporarily close our restaurants in the UK and Ireland for the safety of our people and customers. Recently, we began working through a potential and limited reopening."We have been listening to our employees and customers as well as engaging with government and trade bodies to help ensure we do this responsibly, when the time is right."Restarting our business is not an easy task even when reopening in a limited capacity. We have set ourselves some key criteria for reopening, all of which take time ndash first and foremost ensuring the wellbeing of our people and creating the right environment for them toto work secondly ensuring we have enough supply of fresh produce and finally working in-step with government guidelines to ensure the safety of our customers."This week we are carrying out some operational tests to explore what our reopening might look like the restaurant where these tests take place will remain closed to the public."These tests will include exploring social distancing measures for our crew, PPE options and opening in a limited capacity."For now we remain closed, and will only reopen when we are absolutely confident we can have the right measures in place to ensure everyonersquos wellbeing.Burger KingBurger King has revealed it will open  more restaurants across the country.The move comes after the recentre-opening of six branches - all offering alimited menu to customers through delivery services including Deliveroo and Just Eat.Burger Kings chief executive Alasdair Murdoch toldThe Mail on Sunday that the next branches to open will be in Edinburgh, Aberdeen, Glasgow, Dundee and Merton in London - however theexact locations have not beenconfirmed.NandosNandorsquos has said it is reopening six of its UK restaurants for delivery from today .The peri-peri chicken last week to serve food for NHS workers and charities.The restaurant chain said it will offer deliveries from its Camberwell, Canary Jubilee, Clink Street and Gloucester Road sites in London.It will also serve customers in Manchester from its Fallowfield and Printworks locations.Nandorsquos said it will offer a reduced delivery menu from these sites, but will not be offering eat-in or collection services.In a statement, Nandorsquos said: ldquoThe menu will be reduced to help the team maintain social distance in the kitchen and food prep areas, but never fear as the majority of Nandorsquos favourites such as peri-peri chicken wings, halloumi and peri chips will now be available to enjoy at home.ldquoEach Nandorsquos restaurant has been working under Public Health England guidelines for the past week on top of their existing health and safety procedures.ldquoEvery member of the team has been washing their hands more frequently while maintaining social distance during shts.ldquoAfter a successful trial re-opening serving meals to local good causes, they are now upping production to serve the public.The company stressed that this is the ldquofirst phase of its reopening plans but more restaurants could follow suit and open for deliveriesit is successful.Nandorsquos said that each restaurant will also continue to cook meals every sht for local charities and NHS workers.KFCKFC is set to reopen moreof its branches across the country after bringing in a new set of rules to keep staff and customers safe.The fast-foodretailer began closing its stores on March  following the governments decision to place the UK on lockdown.At that time, KFC said that it wanted to "protect the wellbeing and safety" of staff and customers, and confirmed that the temporary closures would be menu" to customers and service is delivery-only, available through Deliveroo, Just Eat and Uber Eats for those who live near one of the restaurants.In a statement about reopening stores, KFC explained: "To do this in the right way, wersquove put new processes in place and stepped up our already stringent hygiene measures."Wersquore serving a limited menu, which means we can have a smaller kitchen team to maintain social distancing."Our teams are amazing and wersquod never ask them to come back to workthey werenrsquot comfortable, so theyrsquore ing on an opt-in basis. ldquoThe key title: royal-mail-stop-saturday-letter-deliveries-due-coronavirus-pandemic
story: It said it will continue to provide its letter delivery service from Monday to Friday as normal and said customers ldquoshould continue to post both letters and parcels as usual on Saturday.Royal Mail will continue to collect all mail from businesses, post offices and post boxes, it said.When will Saturday deliveries temporarily stop The will be halted from this weekend .What have Royal Mail said Shane OrsquoRiordain, managing director of marketing, regulation and corporate affairs at Royal Mail, said: ldquoOur postmen and postwomen are working very hard across the UK in challenging conditions.ldquoAs we said at the start of the coronavirus crisis, there will be some disruption to services.ldquoWe understand the importance of the postal service in keeping the UK connected at this time.ldquoWe have also listened to our hard-working colleagues who have asked us to ease the additional burden on thempossible. As a result, we are making some temporary changes to postal services.Royal Mail said it has been in dialogue with the Government and regulator Ofcom throughout the crisis and will keep the temporary change to postal arrangements under review.Reaction to the moveThe decision was criticised by the Communication Workersrsquo Union , which represents postal workers.A CWU spokesman said: ldquoWe will be seeking urgent discussions with the Government on this issue.ldquoThe reduction of the Universal Service Obligation was a key factor in our live national strike ballot.ldquoThe last thing we want to do is call strike action at this point but we will not sit back and see our membersrsquo jobs put at threat and the service to the public worsened.Last month the union called for householdsrsquo deliveries to be cut to three days a week due to coronavirus.

title: teachers-well-placed-assess-students-grades
story: The Scottish Qualications Authorityhas revealed how it aims to determine the  exam results for students due to sit them, following the suspension of normal examinations due to Covid-.And Lesley Brown, the councilrsquos chief operating officer for education, said schools were prepared to provide the evidence needed and review the results using their professional judgement.She said: ldquoWe know that the closure of schools and the cancellation of exams has caused anxiety and uncertainty for our pupils and their families. Irsquom pleased that the SQA has now confirmed its approach, and I am especially pleased to see recognition that teachers and schools are best-placed to provide a judgement on pupilsrsquo achievements.ldquoOur schools regularly monitor and track pupilsrsquo progress throughout the academic year as part of our approaches to ensuring high-quality learning, teaching and assessment. Teachersrsquo professional judgement is at the heart of our approach in Scotland and our teachers are very well placed to provide the information required by SQA.ldquoWe are working with our headteachers and school teams to make sure that our approach across East Lothian is consistent, rigorous and accurately reflects pupilsrsquo achievements. Our teachers will estimate grades using all evidence available to them, with support from their subject faculties, wider school teams and from our central education team.The SQA says its approach to awarding grades is based on safe and secure certication following public health advice and maintaining the integrity and credibility of the qualications system.Schools and colleges will be asked to provide the SQA with estimates on pupilsrsquo achievements, grades, bands and rank based on their performance so far in subject activities.This will provide an overall judgement from those the SQA describes as ldquobest placed to do so, with submissions due by May .The SQA will then check and validate the estimates it receives and look at prior assessments undertaken by pupilsthey are available ndash for example, Higher results for an Advanced Higher pupil.The schoolsrsquo previous history in estimating attainment will be considered and SQA will hold Awarding Meetings with its subject experts.Results will be delivered to learners by August  and students are encouraged to register for MySQA to receive their results by text and or email.The appeals process will remain free for schools and colleges so they can advocate on their pupilsrsquo behalfthe results do not reflect the candidatersquos achievements.The SQA has an exams QA for parents and pupils on its website, www.sqa.org.uk

title: pubs-may-limit-drinkers-three-pints-lockdown-lifted
story: Heres what you need to know.What social distancing rules could pubs face When pubs reopen for business, patrons could be limited to three drinks each before being asked to head home, in order to free up space for others to visit, a government advisor has suggested.The strict rules would also include maintaining a social distance of two metres while inside, with landlords able to issue fines to those who flout the rules.The terms are outlined in a plan by economist and government advisor, Professor Eyal Winter, who said social distancing is the key to coming out of lockdown. He also argued that the public need to know what the government has planned in terms of a lockdown exit strategy.Speaking to , he said: ldquoPeople are starving for pubs. They are an important part of British culture.ldquoOne of the most important things is to have a programme, to say, lsquoIn two weeks we will do such and such.rsquoldquoYou need to make the rules crystal clear, and to explain to the public the rationale behind each one of them.When are pubs likely to reopen Professor Winter estimated that it will take ldquoa lot of time to move back to how le was in January , but was certain that the country ldquowill get there.The Mail Online has reported that a possible exit plan could see the UK come out of lockdown in phases. The public would allegedly be allowed back into outdoor spaces first, with pubs being the last to open, as the lockdown was lted.Cabinet Office minister, Michael Gove, confirmed that areas of hospitality will be among the last to see restrictions lted.When asked whether pubs would open ldquobefore winter, Mr Gove told Sky News: ldquoThe other inference that I draw from your question, which is that areas of hospitality will be among the last to exit the lockdown - yes, that is true.What about cinemas and theatres Professor Winter has also been advising ministers on how to go about lting lockdown, and said cinemas and theatres could also reopen, but must have half empty auditoriums.Every other seat would have to be unoccupied, but he said venues could make up for the loss of money by raising ticket prices.

title: neighbours-join-forces-ensure-memorable-80th-birthday
story: James Walker, known as Jim, lives on St Margarets Road with we Valerie and celebrated his big day on Monday.Initial plans were for his daughter Morag to travel from Ireland, where she currently stays with her partner and family, and his two sons Alastair and Graeme to visit from Staffordshire and Edinburgh respectively.However, the coronavirus lockdown changed this, and meant that his family were not able to be by his side.Morag contacted Jim and Valrsquos lsquolockdown street linkrsquo for the area ndash put in place by the townrsquos resilience team ndash to askanyone could make a cake for her dadrsquos birthday.Morag said: ldquoI knew the street link lady is an active member of the community so would knowanyone was able to help.The plan snowballed from a kind neighbour making a chocolate cake to other neighbours gathering in front of Jim and Valeriersquos house to sing a socially distanced lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo.When he heard his doorbell ring, Jim was amazed to find the chocolate cake at the front door.Neighbours from nearby Marmion Road and St Margarets Road struck up a chorus of lsquoHappy Birthdayrsquo, while Jim waved from the doorstep.He then walked to the pavement to thank everyone.ldquoItrsquos a lovely day for us to eat cake and have a cup of tea in the garden, said we Valerie.Morag said: ldquoMy dad was a bit taken aback but really appreciated the surprise. Hersquos looking forward to trying the cake.Jim was born in Gullane on April ,  but has spent most of his le in North Berwick, attending the local schools.He spent all of his career as a quantity surveyor and is a member of the local bowling club.He met Valerie, who is from Prestonpans, at the Pavilion dances in North Berwick, where the Scottish Seabird Centre now stands.The pair married  years ago.Morag said: ldquoWe were going to come over with the whole family and help him celebrate. title: bridges-project-continues-vital-work-lockdown
story: Regular face-to-face sessions and group activities at the Bridges Project on Bogpark Road have been replaced with phone calls, text messages, video calls and digital work as the lockdown becomes challenging for some.Despite the dficult times as a result of the pandemic, staff have discovered ldquopositive elements of lsquoremotersquo working with young people in East Lothian and Midlothian. They have now been working from home for more than a month and have continued to support vulnerable and disadvantaged young people with ious issues which has brought about some ldquounexpected outcomes.Lynne Anderson, transitions development worker, has noticed that she is able to use her time more wisely by phoning her clients instead of driving up to an hour each way to visit them at their homes.She said: ldquoWe can use this situation to learn how things work dferently. There are opportunities to continue doing some of the activities we are doing remotely when weto normal.She is one of several staff members who have had to change the way they give support over the past weeks but it still focuses on many of the same issues. They provide help with filling out job and college applications, and provide young people with emotional support and tutoring. The response has also generally been very positive, with staff members reporting engagement levels of up to  per cent from their clients.Natasha McInninie, transitions service co-ordinator, said: ldquoI am surprised by how resilient young people are. I thought we would lose a lot of young people through this situation. However, it has actually made them engage more.Emma Scarclfe, acting chief executive, is also very pleased by how both Bridges Project staff and the young people they work with have responded to the current crisis.She said: ldquoBridges Project has adapted quickly to the unexpected situation around Covid-. Engagement continues to be extremely high and the commitment and dedication from staff to change their working practices so quickly to suit each inidual young person has been a complete triumph. Wersquore all very proud of the way young people have adapted and how resilient they are.However, there are also issues which have become ldquomagnied during the lockdown, for example, people who have dficult relationships with their family members struggle with being ldquolocked up together over such a long period. Others are affected by less income and need help with accessing food parcels, Universal Credit and other types of financial support.Many young people also need help to deal with the impact the Covid- crisis is having on their mental health. This is particularly the case for those who were already struggling with social anxiety or social isolation prior to the lockdown.Lynne said: ldquoIn the beginning, the young people thought it was fantastic. Now the reality of the lockdown is settling in and it is starting to become challenging.This trend has also been observed by personal development worker, Chris Nicol, who said: ldquoThe young people were dealing with it well during the first few weeks but have seen a downturn in their mood over the last two weeks. This is due to a combination of boredom and too much time to think but also not seeing their friends. They have realised how important those social anchors really are.He highlighted the importance of keeping young peoplersquos motivation and confidence up during these challenging times.He explained: ldquoI remind them that they need to focus on the fact that this will last for a relatively short period of their lives and things will go back to normal.Thank you for reading this story. title: uk-lockdown-eased-schools-travel-sport
story: This will be a ldquomenu of options with the dates and times driven by the current state of the outbreak in the UK, he added.Ministers have faced continued questioning over the UKrsquos plan for lting its coronavirus lockdown, as European countries begin to ease their own restrictions.Italy and Spain are among those planning small steps to relax measures, while the Scottish and Welsh governments have set out dferent visions of how the current restrictions could be lted when the outbreak is under control.The next three-week review of the lockdown restrictions is due on Thursday, May .But how could the lockdown be lted across ious sectors  Heres a round-up of what you need to know.SchoolsUnder lockdown, schools and colleges have largely been closed, except for the children of essential workers, and it is thought this could be among the first restrictions to be eased.But Education Secretary Gavin Williamson previously said the Government had ldquono plans to open schools over the summer period, while Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said it would be ldquoinconceivable without some further measures in place.Head teachers have previously been advised to start making preparations on how schools could safely reopen, with the Association of School and College Leaderssuggesting a staggeredof pupils.ConstructionSome of Britainrsquos largest housebuilders ndash including Persimmon, Taylor Wimpey and Redrow ndash have already announced plans to reopen building sites in late April or early May.Under Government guidance, construction has been permittedin accordance with social distancing rules, but many companies halted work in response to the crisis.The Home Builders Federation said the restart is expected to be gradual, being dependent on how far supporting suppliers and services, such as building inspectors, mortgage lenders and conveyancers, can alsoto work.Activity will also be limited until the Government changes advice which effectively prohibits all but exceptional house moves.OfficesProperty services provider CBRE has drawn from its experiences in Asia to issue guidance to workplaces on how offices might approach re-opening in the future.It advises against a ldquofull throttleto work, with social-distancing measures needing to be reduced gradually and in line with public health guidance.It suggests businesses should establish internal taskforces to consider issues around access to PPE supplies, touchless technologies, temperature screening and reconfiguring work environments.Social gatheringsLimited social gatherings could be permitted in an easing of lockdown, but should be accompanied by extensive testing and contact tracing, one expert has suggested.Dr Joshua Moon, research fellow in sustainability research methods in the Science Policy Research Unitat the University of Sussex Business School, said the Government could adopt a ldquoslow release valve approach to the issue.He explained a phased approach might see certain sections of the population, for example healthy middle-aged people, given more freedoms initially, but he warned this risked the most vulnerable suffering the hardships of lockdown the longest.Dr Moon said family ldquoclusters could gradually be permitted to socialise, but could not make long journeys to do so, while most businesses remained shut.ldquoThe idea is that within those groups you can quite easily test, trace and isolate, he said, adding that it was harder to monitor for people moving around in public.HospitalitySector representative body UKHospitality has focused its energies on getting business support extended to places like bars and restaurants.A spokesman suggested that evenvenues were allowed to open with reduced capacity, businesses would still struggle financially.The All Party Parliamentary Group for Hospitality and Tourism has launched an urgent inquiry into how the sectors could reopen.This includes looking at operational challenges, reactivating supply chains, Government support and encouraging demand. A report is expected by mid-May.Pub chain Wetherspoonrsquos has said it plans to reopen its bars and hotels in June and said that due to it having larger than average pubs social distancing measures could be applied.RetailMinisters are thought to be considering allowing some non-essential businesses to open, such as garden centres and car showrooms, provided social-distancing could be maintained.Lobby group the British Retail Consortium has produced guidelines on how stores could prepare for the easing of restrictions.The guidance draws on lessons learned from supermarkets in recent weeks to ensure the re-opening of non-essential firms can be done safely.Advice coverslimiting entry and exit points, using floor markings to outline social distancing and keeping changing rooms closed.The guidance also suggests installing cleaning stations with hand sanitiser and disinfectant wipes at the front of stores.SportIt is understood Culture Secretary Olive Dowden has been working on a plan for major sports to be played behind closed doors when some social-distancing rules are eased.Weekly meetings are to be held between the Government, Public Health England and medical officials from sports bodies, with the issue due to be on the table when ministers review current measures next month.Key questions that need to be tackled include testing requirements, burdens on emergency services and the possible impact on fan behaviour ndash such as impromptu gatherings outside grounds.Sporting bodies are understood to be keen to resume full training safely as soon as possible.TravelLast week, low-cost European carrier Wizz Air announced plans to resume some flights from Luton Airport on May .Cabin crew will be required to wear masks and gloves on all flights and will distribute sanitising wipes for passengers, while new distancing measures will also be introduced during boarding.Mr Raab has indicated that officials are looking at possible checks at air and sea ports, with passengers arriving in the UK required to quarantine for  days.Meanwhile, the Rail, Maritime and Transportunion warned there was ldquozero chance of ramping up transport services soon, amid speculation of an increase on May  or May  when a new rail timetable is due.Last week, industry sources said no dates have yet been agreed or announced.
